column1: ==Debate about a potential future of nations==

{{See also|Clash of Civilizations|City-state|Virtual community|Tribe (Internet)|Global citizenship|Geographic mobility|Transnationalism|Geo-fence|Decentralization|Collective problem solving|Sociocultural evolution}}

There is an ongoing debate about the future of nations − about whether this framework will persist as is and whether there are viable or developing alternatives.<ref name=news>{{cite magazine|title=End of nations: Is there an alternative to countries?|url=http://mpc-journal.org/blog/2016/11/09/end-of-nations-is-there-an-alternative-to-countries/|magazine=New Scientist|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>

The theory of the [[clash of civilizations]] lies in direct contrast to [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] theories about an ever more-connected world that no longer requires nation states. According to [[political scientist]] [[Samuel P. Huntington]]
column2: people's cultural and religious [[Identity (social science)|identities]] will be the primary source of conflict in the post–[[Cold War]] world.

column1: The theory was originally formulated in a 1992 lecture<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aei.org/issue/29196 |title=U.S. Trade Policy — Economics |publisher=AEI |date=15 February 2007 |accessdate=20 February 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629170348/http://www.aei.org/issue/29196 |archivedate=29 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> at the [[American Enterprise Institute]]
column2: which was then developed in a 1993 ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' article titled \"The Clash of Civilizations?\"
column3: <ref name=\"FAarticle\">Official copy (free preview): {{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.org/19930601faessay5188/samuel-p-huntington/the-clash-of-civilizations.html|title=The Clash of Civilizations?|work=[[Foreign Affairs]]|date=Summer 1993|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629022856/http://www.foreignaffairs.org/19930601faessay5188/samuel-p-huntington/the-clash-of-civilizations.html|archivedate=29 June 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in response to [[Francis Fukuyama]]'s 1992 book
column4: ''[[The End of History and the Last Man]]''. Huntington later expanded his [[thesis]] in a 1996 book ''The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order''.

column1: Huntington began his thinking by surveying the diverse theories about the nature of global politics in the post–[[Cold War]] period. Some theorists and writers argued that [[human rights]]
column2: [[liberal democracy]] and capitalist [[free market]] economics had become the only remaining ideological alternative for nations in the post–Cold War world. Specifically
column4: in ''[[The End of History and the Last Man]]''
column5: argued that the world had reached a [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegelian]] \"end of history\".

column1: Huntington believed that while the age of [[ideology]] had ended
column2: the world had reverted only to a normal state of affairs characterized by cultural conflict. In his thesis
column3: he argued that the primary axis of conflict in the future will be along cultural and religious lines.

column1: [[Postnationalism]] is the process or trend by which nation states and national identities lose their importance relative to supranational and global entities. Several factors contribute to its aspects including [[economic globalization]]
column2: a rise in importance of [[multinational corporation]]s
column4: the transfer of [[socio-political power]] from national authorities to supernational entities
column5: such as multinational corporations
column6: the [[United Nations]] and the [[European Union]] and the advent of new information and culture technologies such as the [[Internet]]. However attachment to citizenship and [[national identities]] often remains important.<ref>R. Koopmans and P. Statham; \"Challenging the liberal nation-state? Postnationalism
column7: multiculturalism
column8: and the collective claims making of migrants and ethnic minorities in Britain and Germany\"; ''American Journal of Sociology'' 105:652–96 (1999)</ref><ref>R.A. Hackenberg and R.R. Alvarez; \"Close-ups of postnationalism: Reports from the US-Mexico borderlands\"; ''Human Organization'' 60:97–104 (2001)</ref><ref>I. Bloemraad; \"Who claims dual citizenship? The limits of postnationalism
column9: the possibilities of transnationalism
column10: and the persistence of traditional citizenship\"; ''International Migration Review'' 38:389–426 (2004)</ref>

column1: Jan Zielonka of the University of Oxford states that \"the future structure and exercise of political power will resemble the medieval model more than the Westphalian one\" with the latter being about \"concentration of power
column2: sovereignty and clear-cut identity\" and [[neo-medievalism]] meaning \"overlapping authorities
column4: multiple identities and governing institutions
column5: and fuzzy borders\".<ref name=news/>

column1: American political scientist [[Benedict Anderson]] characterised a nation as an \"[[imagined community]]\"
column2: <ref>{{cite book |last= Anderson |first= Benedict | title= Imagined Communities | publisher= Verso Publications | location= London |year= 1983}}</ref> and Australian academic [[Paul James (academic)|Paul James]] sees it as an \"abstract community\".<ref>{{Cite book | last= James | first= Paul |authorlink= Paul James (academic) | title= Nation Formation: Towards a Theory of Abstract Community | url= https://www.academia.edu/40353321 |publisher= Sage Publications | location= London |year= 1996 | page= 34 | quote = A nation is at once an objectively abstract society of strangers
column4: and a subjectively embodied community whose members experience themselves as an integrated group of compatriots.}}</ref> A nation is an imagined community in the sense that the material conditions exist for imagining extended and shared connections and that it is objectively impersonal
column5: even if each individual in the nation experiences him or herself as subjectively part of an embodied unity with others. For the most part
column6: members of a nation remain strangers to each other and will likely never meet.<ref>{{cite book | last= James | first= Paul |authorlink= Paul James (academic) |title= Globalism
column7: Nationalism
column8: Tribalism: Bringing Theory Back In |url= https://www.academia.edu/1642214 |date= 2006 | publisher= Sage Publications |location= London }}</ref> Hence the phrase
column9: \"a nation of strangers\" used by such writers as American journalist [[Vance Packard]]. So
column10: a nation is an [[intersubjective]] reality and exists solely in the collective imagination of the citizens. Even if a person comes to believe that a nation does not exist
column11: the nation will remain unharmed
column12: as it is not a [[wikt:subjective|subjective]] reality which exists in the mind of a single person. Only if a very large number of people come to believe that the nation should not exist and end its validity will the nation cease to exist.<ref name=\"news\" /><ref>homo deus by Yuval Noah Harari </ref><ref>

column1: The word ''nation'' came from the [[Old French]] word ''nacion'' – meaning \"birth\" (''naissance'')
column3: which in turn originates from the [[Latin language|Latin]] word ''[[wikt:Special:Search/natio|natio]]'' (''nātĭō'') literally meaning \"birth\".<ref name=\"etymonline\">{{cite web |last=Harper |first=Douglas |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=nation |title=Nation |work=Online Etymology Dictionary |accessdate=5 June 2011}}.</ref>

column1: ''[[Black's Law Dictionary]]'' defines a nation as follows:

column2: ''n.'' (14c) '''1.''' A large group of people having a common origin
column4: and tradition and usu. constituting a political entity. • When a nation is coincident with a state
column5: the term ''nation-state'' is often used....

column1: '''2.''' A community of people inhabiting a defined territory and organized under an independent government; a sovereign political state....<ref name = \"black\">{{cite book
|editor-first= Bryan A. |editor-last= Garner|author-link= Bryan A. Garner}}
The word \"nation\" is sometimes used as synonym for:
* [[State (polity)]] or [[sovereign state]]: a government which controls a specific territory
column2: which may or may not be associated with any particular ethnic group
which may or may not have an affiliation with a government or ethnic group

column1: Thus the phrase \"nations of the world\" could be referring to the top-level governments (as in the name for the [[United Nations]])
column3: or various large ethnic groups of the planet.

column1: Depending on the meaning of \"nation\" used
column2: the term \"[[nation state]]\" could be used to distinguish larger states from small [[city state]]s
column3: or could be used to distinguish [[multinational state]]s from those with a single ethnic group.

column1: In her book ''Kingdoms and Communities in Western Europe 900–1300''
column2: [[Susan Reynolds]] argues that many European medieval kingdoms were nations in the modern sense except that political participation in nationalism was available only to a limited prosperous and literate class.<ref>Susan Reynolds
column3: Kingdoms and Communities in Western Europe 900–1300
column4: Oxford
column5: 1997.</ref> In his book ''The Construction of Nationhood: Ethnicity
column6: Religion and Nationalism''
column7: [[Adrian Hastings]] states that England's Anglo Saxon kings mobilized mass nationalism in their struggle to repel Norse invasions. He argues that [[Alfred the Great]]
column8: in particular
column9: drew on [[biblical nationalism]]
column10: using biblical language in his law code and that during his reign selected books of the Bible were translated into [[Old English]] to inspire Englishmen to fight to turn back the Norse invaders. Hastings argues for a strong renewal of English nationalism (following a hiatus after the [[Norman conquest]]) beginning with the [[Wycliffe's Bible|translation of the complete bible into English by the Wycliffe circle in the 1380s]]
column11: positing that [[English nationalism]] and the English nation have been continuous since that time.<ref>Adrian Hastings
column12: The Construction of Nationhood: Ethnicity
column13: Religion and Nationalism. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press

column1: Another prudent example of Medieval nationalism is the [[Declaration of Arbroath]]
column2: a document produced by Scottish nobles and clergy during the [[Scottish Wars of Independence]]. The purpose of the document was to demonstrate to the Pope that Scotland was indeed a nation of its own
column4: history and language and that it was indeed an older nation than England. The document went on to justify the actions of [[Robert the Bruce]] and his forces in resisting the occupation and to chastise the English for having violated Scottish sovereignty without justification. The propaganda campaign supplemented a military campaign on the part of the Bruce
column5: which after the [[Battle of Bannockburn]] was successful and eventually resulted in the end of England's occupation and recognition of Scottish independence on the part of the English crown. The document is widely seen as an early example of both [[Scottish nationalism]] and [[popular sovereignty]].

column1: [[Anthony Kaldellis]] affirms in ''Hellenism in Byzantium'' (2008) that what is called the [[Byzantine Empire]] was the Roman Empire transformed into a [[nation-state]] in Middle Ages.
Azar Gat is among the scholars who argue that [[China]]
column2: [[Korea]] and [[Japan]] were nations by the time of the European Middle Ages.<ref>Azar Gat
column3: ''Nations: The Long History and Deep Roots of Political Ethnicity and Nationalism''
column4: Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. 2013
column5: China
column6: p. 93 Korea
column7: p. 104 and Japan p.

column1: ===Use of term ''nationes'' by medieval universities and other medieval institutions===
A significant early use of the term ''nation''
column3: occurred at [[Medieval university|Medieval universities]]<ref>''see: [[nation (university)]]''</ref> to describe the colleagues in a college or students
column4: above all at the [[University of Paris]]
column5: who were all born within a ''pays''
column6: spoke the same language and expected to be ruled by their own familiar law. In 1383 and 1384
column7: while studying theology at Paris
column8: [[Jean Gerson]] was elected twice as a procurator for the French ''natio''. The [[Charles University in Prague|University of Prague]] adopted the division of students into ''nationes'': from its opening in 1349 the ''[[studium generale]]'' which consisted of Bohemian
column9: Bavarian
column10: Saxon and Silesian ''nations''.

column2: the ''nationes'' were segregated by the [[Knights Hospitaller|Knights Hospitaller of Jerusalem]]
column3: who maintained at [[Rhodes]] the hostels from which they took their name \"where foreigners eat and have their places of meeting
column4: each nation apart from the others
column5: and a Knight has charge of each one of these hostels
column6: and provides for the necessities of the inmates according to their religion\"
column7: as the Spanish traveller [[Pedro Tafur]] noted in 1436.<ref>Pedro Tafur
column8: ''[http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/tafur.html#ch5 Andanças e viajes]''.</ref>

column2: \"The Mosaic Moment: An Early Modernist Critique of the Modernist Theory of Nationalism\"

column3: the [[civic nation]] of which France was the principal example and the [[ethnic nationalism|ethnic nation]] exemplified by the German peoples. The German tradition was conceptualized as originating with early 19th-century philosophers
column4: like [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte]]
column5: and referred to people sharing a common language
column6: religion
column7: culture
column8: history
column9: and [[ethnic origins]]
column10: that differentiate them from people of other nations.<ref name=Noiriel>{{cite book|last=Noiriel|first=Gérard|title=Population

column12: the civic nation was traced to the [[French Revolution]] and ideas deriving from 18th-century French philosophers. It was understood as being centered in a willingness to \"live together\"

column1: ==Debate about a potential future of nations==

{{See also|Clash of Civilizations|City-state|Virtual community|Tribe (Internet)|Global citizenship|Geographic mobility|Transnationalism|Geo-fence|Decentralization|Collective problem solving|Sociocultural evolution}}

There is an ongoing debate about the future of nations − about whether this framework will persist as is and whether there are viable or developing alternatives.<ref name=news>{{cite magazine|title=End of nations: Is there an alternative to countries?|url=http://mpc-journal.org/blog/2016/11/09/end-of-nations-is-there-an-alternative-to-countries/|magazine=New Scientist|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>

The theory of the [[clash of civilizations]] lies in direct contrast to [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] theories about an ever more-connected world that no longer requires nation states. According to [[political scientist]] [[Samuel P. Huntington]]
column2: people's cultural and religious [[Identity (social science)|identities]] will be the primary source of conflict in the post–[[Cold War]] world.

column1: The theory was originally formulated in a 1992 lecture<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aei.org/issue/29196 |title=U.S. Trade Policy — Economics |publisher=AEI |date=15 February 2007 |accessdate=20 February 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629170348/http://www.aei.org/issue/29196 |archivedate=29 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> at the [[American Enterprise Institute]]
column2: which was then developed in a 1993 ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' article titled \"The Clash of Civilizations?\"
column3: <ref name=\"FAarticle\">Official copy (free preview): {{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.org/19930601faessay5188/samuel-p-huntington/the-clash-of-civilizations.html|title=The Clash of Civilizations?|work=[[Foreign Affairs]]|date=Summer 1993|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629022856/http://www.foreignaffairs.org/19930601faessay5188/samuel-p-huntington/the-clash-of-civilizations.html|archivedate=29 June 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in response to [[Francis Fukuyama]]'s 1992 book
column4: ''[[The End of History and the Last Man]]''. Huntington later expanded his [[thesis]] in a 1996 book ''The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order''.

column1: Huntington began his thinking by surveying the diverse theories about the nature of global politics in the post–[[Cold War]] period. Some theorists and writers argued that [[human rights]]
column2: [[liberal democracy]] and capitalist [[free market]] economics had become the only remaining ideological alternative for nations in the post–Cold War world. Specifically
column4: in ''[[The End of History and the Last Man]]''
column5: argued that the world had reached a [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegelian]] \"end of history\".

column1: Huntington believed that while the age of [[ideology]] had ended
column2: the world had reverted only to a normal state of affairs characterized by cultural conflict. In his thesis
column3: he argued that the primary axis of conflict in the future will be along cultural and religious lines.

column1: [[Postnationalism]] is the process or trend by which nation states and national identities lose their importance relative to supranational and global entities. Several factors contribute to its aspects including [[economic globalization]]
column2: a rise in importance of [[multinational corporation]]s
column4: the transfer of [[socio-political power]] from national authorities to supernational entities
column5: such as multinational corporations
column6: the [[United Nations]] and the [[European Union]] and the advent of new information and culture technologies such as the [[Internet]]. However attachment to citizenship and [[national identities]] often remains important.<ref>R. Koopmans and P. Statham; \"Challenging the liberal nation-state? Postnationalism
column7: multiculturalism
column8: and the collective claims making of migrants and ethnic minorities in Britain and Germany\"; ''American Journal of Sociology'' 105:652–96 (1999)</ref><ref>R.A. Hackenberg and R.R. Alvarez; \"Close-ups of postnationalism: Reports from the US-Mexico borderlands\"; ''Human Organization'' 60:97–104 (2001)</ref><ref>I. Bloemraad; \"Who claims dual citizenship? The limits of postnationalism
column9: the possibilities of transnationalism
column10: and the persistence of traditional citizenship\"; ''International Migration Review'' 38:389–426 (2004)</ref>

column1: Jan Zielonka of the University of Oxford states that \"the future structure and exercise of political power will resemble the medieval model more than the Westphalian one\" with the latter being about \"concentration of power
column2: sovereignty and clear-cut identity\" and [[neo-medievalism]] meaning \"overlapping authorities
column4: multiple identities and governing institutions
column5: and fuzzy borders\".<ref name=news/>

column1: There is no governing body that declares any regulations on what constitutes a skateboard or the parts from which it is assembled. Historically
column2: the skateboard has conformed both to contemporary trends and to the ever-evolving array of stunts performed by riders/users
column3: who require a certain functionality from the board. The board shape depends largely upon its desired function. [[Longboard (skateboard)|Longboards]] are a type of skateboard with a longer [[wheelbase]] and larger
column4: softer wheels.

column1: The two main types of skateboards are the longboard and the shortboard. The shape of the board is also important: the skateboard must be concaved to perform tricks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/339215-skateboards-fit-types/ |title=Skateboards: Fit & Types |publisher=LiveStrong |accessdate=June 23
column3: 2012 |url-status=live}}</ref> Longboards are usually faster and are mostly used for cruising and racing
column4: while shortboards are mostly used for doing tricks and riding in skateparks.

column1: Skateboarding started in California in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thoughtco.com/brief-history-of-skateboarding-3002042 |title=Skateboarding: From Wooden Box Boards to Commercial Mainstream |publisher= |access-date=May 6
column3: 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> The first skateboards were made from [[roller skates]] (attached to a board).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teacher.scholastic.com/scholasticnews/indepth/Skateboarding/articles/index.asp?article=history&topic=0 |title=Scholastic News: Skateboarding|website=teacher.scholastic.com |access-date=March 26
column4: 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180403111056/http://teacher.scholastic.com/scholasticnews/indepth/Skateboarding/articles/index.asp?article=history&topic=0 |archive-date=April 3
column5: 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Skateboarding gained in popularity because of surfing: in fact
column6: skateboarding was initially referred to as \"sidewalk surfing\". Initially
column7: skateboards were handmade from wooden boxes and planks by individuals. Companies started manufacturing skateboards in 1959
column8: as the sport became more popular.<ref>{{Citation |title=The mix of sunshine and rebellion is really intoxicating|work=Skate Life|pages=27–77 |publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472900459|doi=10.2307/j.ctv65sw5s.5|year=2010}}</ref> In postwar America
column9: society was carefree with children commonly playing in the streets.<ref>{{Citation |title=The mix of sunshine and rebellion is really intoxicating|work=Skate Life|pages=27–77 |publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472900459|doi=10.2307/j.ctv65sw5s.5|year=2010}}</ref> Boards were also continuing to evolve as companies tried to make them lighter
column10: stronger and improve their performance.

column1: [[Image:Skateboard.JPG|thumb|The side of a skateboard]] Modern decks vary in size
column2: but most are {{convert|7|to|10.5|in|cm}} wide. Wider decks can be used for greater stability when skateboarding. Standard skateboard decks are usually between {{convert|28|and|33|in|cm}} long. The underside of the deck can be printed with a design by the manufacturer
column4: or decorated by any other means.

column2: a common variant of the skateboard
column3: is used for higher speed and rough surface boarding
column4: and they are much more expensive. \"Old school\" boards (those made in the 1970s–80s or modern boards that mimic their shape) are generally wider and often have only one kicktail. Variants of the 1970s often have little or no concavity
column5: whereas 1980s models have deeper concavities and steeper kicktails.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://skatesradar.com/skateboard/ |title= SKATEBOARDS |accessdate= August 30
column6: 2017|date= June 15
column7: 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170830010205/http://skatesradar.com/skateboard/ |archive-date= August 30
column8: 2017 |url-status= live}}</ref>

column1: Grip tape is a sheet of paper or fabric with adhesive on one side and a surface similar to fine sandpaper on the other. Rubber grip tape is also available
column2: which has gathered some popularity due to the lack of damage it causes to skate shoes. Grip tape is applied to the top surface of a board to allow the rider's feet to grip the surface and help the skater stay on the board while doing tricks. Grip tape is usually black
column3: but is also available in many different colors such as pink
column4: red
column5: yellow
column6: checkered
column7: camo
column8: and even clear. Often
column9: they have designs die-cut to show the color of the board
column10: or to display the board's company logo. Grip tape accumulates dirt and other substances that will inhibit grip
column11: so use of a grip eraser or rubber eraser is necessary after riding through mud or with dirty shoes.

column1: Attached to the deck are two metal (usually made of [[aluminum alloy]]) trucks
column2: which connect the wheels and bearings to the deck. The trucks are further composed of two parts.

column1: The top part of the truck is screwed to the deck and is called the ''baseplate''
column2: and beneath it is the ''hanger''. The axle runs through the hanger. Between the baseplate and the hanger are ''[[Bushing (isolator)|bushings]]''
column4: that provide the cushion mechanism for turning the skateboard. The ''bushings'' cushion the truck when it turns. The stiffer the bushings
column5: the more resistant the skateboard is to turning. The softer the bushings
column6: the easier it is to turn. Bushings come in varying shapes and urethane formulas as well as [[durometer]]s
column7: which may affect turning
column8: rebound and durability. A bolt called a ''[[Kingpin (mechanics)|kingpin]]'' holds these parts together and fits inside the bushings. Thus by tightening or loosening the kingpin nut
column9: the trucks can be loosened for increased turning or tightened for more stability. The standard kingpin nut size is {{frac|3|8}} - [[Threads per inch|24]] [[Unified Thread Standard#Designation|UNF]].

column1: The position of the hanger with respect to the baseplate is determined by the ''pivot''
column2: a rod that slots into the corresponding seat in the baseplate. The pivot stops the hanger from rotating around the kingpin. The pivot must allow some movement around the bushings and therefore is not a perfect fit. The space between the pivot and its seat in the baseplate is filled by a ''pivot cup''
column3: a plastic part that takes most of the wear and tear of the pivot and assists in centering. The pivot cup should be periodically lubricated to ensure a smooth turn.

column2: an axle width should be chosen that is close to the width of the deck it will be used with.<ref>Has a guide to choosing the right size trucks for a skateboard deck http://skate-parts.com/blog/choosing-right-size-trucks-your-skateboard-deck {{Webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426135324/http://skate-parts.com/blog/choosing-right-size-trucks-your-skateboard-deck |date=April 26
column4: a {{convert|7.75|in|cm|1|abbr=on}} wide deck will usually be fitted with trucks that have axles between {{convert|7.5|in|cm|1|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|8.0|in|cm|1|abbr=on}} wide. (Standard truck axle nut size is {{frac|5|16}} - 24 UNF
column5: and the thinner \"jam\" style with an optional nylon lock.) Trucks that are too wide can make doing tricks difficult and can cause the wheels to get in the way when the skateboard is being ridden. Trucks that are too small reduce stability and can cause wheel bite to occur more easily when turning.

column1: Longboard-specific trucks are a recent development. A longboard truck has the kingpin laid at a more obtuse angle (usually between 38 and 50 degrees<ref>Contains a list of dimensions for popular longboard truck manufacturer {{cite web |url=http://www.randal.com/guides_faq.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 1
column4: giving a greater degree of turning for the same tilt of the deck. Many longboard-specific trucks also have a reverse kingpin arrangement with the kingpins facing outward.

column1: The [[wheel]]s of a skateboard are usually made of [[polyurethane]]
column2: and come in many different sizes and shapes to suit different types of skating. Larger diameters ({{convert|55–85|mm|in|2|abbr=in|disp=or}}) roll faster
column3: and move more easily over cracks in pavement and are better for transition skateboarding. Smaller diameters ({{convert|48–54|mm|in|abbr=in|2|disp=or}}) keep the board closer to the ground
column4: require less force to accelerate and produce a lower center of gravity which allows for a better response time
column5: but also make for a slower top speed and are better for street skateboarding. Wheels also are available in a variety of hardnesses usually measured on the [[Shore durometer]] \"A\" scale. Again like car tires
column6: wheels range from the very soft (about Shore A 75) to the very hard (about Shore A 101). As the A scale stops at 100
column7: any wheels labeled 101A or higher are harder
column8: but do not use the appropriate durometer scale. Some wheel manufacturers now use the \"B\" or \"D\" scales
column9: which have a larger and more accurate range of hardness. Modern street skaters prefer medium-sized wheels (usually {{convert|51–54|mm|in|abbr=in|2|disp=or}})
column10: as small wheels with lighter trucks can make [[Skateboarding trick|tricks]] like [[kickflip]]s and other flip tricks easier by keeping the center of gravity of the skateboard closer to the deck
column11: thus making the deck easier to spin. Street wheels are harder (A 100/A 101). [[Vertical ramp]] or \"vert\" skating requires larger wheels (usually {{convert|55–65|mm|in|abbr=in|2|disp=or}})
column12: as it involves higher speeds. Vert wheels are also usually slightly softer (A 98/ A 99)
column13: allowing them to maintain high speed on ramps without sliding. Slalom skating requires even larger wheels ({{convert|60–75|mm|in|2|abbr=in|disp=or}}) to sustain the highest speeds possible. They also need to be soft and have better grip to make the tight and frequent turns in slalom racing. Even larger wheels are used in longboarding and downhill skateboarding. Sizes range from {{convert|60 to 100|mm|in|2|abbr=in}}. These extreme sizes of wheels almost always have cores of hard plastic that can be made thinner and lighter than a solid polyurethane wheel. They are often used by skateboard videographers as well
column14: as they minimize noise and roll smoothly over most types of terrain.

column1: [[File:BallBearing.gif|thumb|An animation of the working principle for a [[ball bearing]]. ''N.B. The diagram shows an 8-balled-bearing whereas a skateboard bearing is typically 7-balled'']]
Each skateboard wheel is mounted on its axle via two [[ball bearing]]s. With few exceptions
column2: the bearings are the industrial standard \"608\" size
column3: with a bore of {{convert|8|mm|in|3|abbr=in}} (or {{convert|10|mm|in|3|abbr=in|disp=sqbr}} depending on the axle)
column4: an outer diameter of {{convert|22|mm|in|3|abbr=in}}
column5: and a width of {{convert|7|mm|in|3|abbr=in}}. These are usually made of steel
column6: though silicon nitride
column7: a high-tech ceramic
column8: is sometimes used. Many skateboard bearings are graded according to the [[ABEC scale]]. The starts with ABEC1 as the lowest
column9: followed by 3
column12: and 9. It is a common misconception that the higher ABECs are better for skateboarding
column13: as the ABEC rating only measures [[Engineering tolerance|tolerances]]
column14: which do not necessarily apply to skateboards. Bearing performance is determined by how well maintained the bearings are. Maintenance on bearings includes periodically cleaning and lubricating them.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://bonesbearings.com/support/maintenance/ |title=Lubrication |access-date=June 4
column16: 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> Bearings that are kept unmaintained have their performance greatly lowered and will soon need to be replaced. Bearing cleaning kits are commonly available on the market. The ABEC rating does not determine the speed or durability of a skateboard bearing. In particular
column17: the ABEC rating says nothing about how well a bearing handles axial (side-to-side) loads
column18: which are severe in most skateboard applications. Many companies do not show the ABEC rating
column19: such as [[Bones Bearings]]
column20: which makes bearings specifically for skateboarding
column21: often marketed as \"Skate Rated\". Each bearing usually contains 7 steel or ceramic [[Ball (bearing)|bearing balls]]
column22: although other configurations are used as well.

column1: Mounting hardware is a set of eight 10-32 UNF bolts
column2: usually an [[Allen wrench|Allen]] or [[Phillips (screw head)|Phillips]] head
column3: and matching nylon [[locknut]]s. They are used to attach the trucks (and any type of risers) to the board. Some sets have one different colored bolt to show which side is the nose of the skateboard. Hardware is available in various lengths for mounting trucks with or without risers.

column1: Risers increase the space between the truck and the deck. This allows the truck to twist further without causing wheel bite (when the wheel touches the deck and stops rotating).

Wedges can be used to change the [[steering|turning]] characteristics of a truck.<ref>A guide describing turning characteristics of different Riser/Wedge types {{cite web |url=http://www.randal.com/guides_faq.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 1

Shock pads are made of polyurethane and rubber. They are very similar to risers but vary in the fact that their sole purpose is to cushion the board from the trucks. Since the trucks are metal and the board wood
column2: whenever the board hits the ground after doing a trick
column3: the energy goes through the truck to the board ─ this has caused boards to crack
column4: split
column5: or even break in half
column6: and shock pads were created to prevent this.

column2: are narrow strips of plastic or metal that are attached under the deck lengthwise along the edges. They are used for additional grip for grabs
column3: and to enhance sliding while protecting the deck's graphics at the same time. Rails also provide a more consistent feel for slides
column4: as the slide of a regular skateboard will suffer from the wear of the paint or varnish on the bottom of the board. Although rarely used anymore
column5: they are useful for experienced skaters that are capable of grabs.

column1: Sliptape is a clear piece of self-adhesive plastic that sticks to the underside of a deck. It helps protect the board's graphics and allows the board to slide more easily. Another name for this is everslick.

A lapper is a plastic cover that is fastened to the rear truck and serves to protect the kingpin when grinding. It also prevents hang-ups by providing a smoother transition for the truck when it hits an obstacle or a metal pipe or round bar.
A nose guard is a plastic bumper used to protect the front of a skateboard which was once popular but is now only commonly seen on older board models.
Bolted onto the underside of the tail end of a skateboard
column2: the tail guard (also known as a \"skid plate\") protected the tail end from skid stops and other maneuvers that would otherwise wear away the wood (commonly known as razor tail) and decrease the longevity of the tail. Typically made of plastic
column3: these were widely popular in the '80s but their usage quickly diminished with the arrival of two-tail board designs
column4: which became increasingly popular in the 1990s.

column1: A \"tail devil\" is a sparking device made of flint which is placed either on the tail or nose of the skateboard (or both) to create a sparking effect mainly visible after dark when the tail or nose of the boards scrapes against the ground.
Plastic half tubing that protected the axles of the trucks. In the 1980–85 period
column2: shopping cart handles were cut by some to fit as a makeshift coper.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}

column1: [[Sublimation (phase transition)]] is the transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas phase without passing through an intermediate liquid phase. Sublimation is an endothermic phase transition that occurs at temperatures and pressures below a substance's triple point in its phase diagram. In this case
column2: ink is transferred to a base layer
column4: through heat and pressure
column5: the result is a full color graphic that will not come off as easily as the more common heat transfers. This application is often found with bamboo boards and composite construction longboards where fibreglass can allow for various degrees of flex or stiffness depending on the ride you're looking for
column6: cruising and carving versus slalom and downhill.

column1: While not part of a skateboard
column2: an all in one skateboard tool capable of mounting and removing trucks & wheels and adjusting truck kingpins are commonly sold by [[skate shop]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fasttech.com/products/1921/10062128/9696858-multifunctional-t-type-roller-hex-socket-wrench |title=Multifunctional T-Type Roller Hex Socket Wrench Skateboard Repair Tool |publisher=fasttech.com |accessdate=15 September 2019}}</ref> Some tools include a metal [[Skateboard#Grip_tape|grip-tape]] [[File_(tool)|file]] and can also be used as a [[bottle-opener]]. Tools which can be used for the purpose of re-threading wheel axles
column3: working with bearings and even applying grip-tape have been developed.
they are said to ride \"[[Footedness#Goofy_stance_vs._Regular_stance|regular]].\" If the rider is normally regular but chooses to ride goofy
column4: they are said to be riding in \"[[Footedness#Switch
column5: _Fakie_and_Nollie|switch]]
column6: \" and vice versa. A skater is typically more comfortable pushing with their back foot; choosing to push with the front foot is commonly referred to as riding \"mongo\"
column7: and has negative connotations of style and effectiveness in the skateboarding community.

column2: [[electric skateboard]]s have also appeared. These no longer require the propelling of the skateboard by means of the feet; rather an electric motor propels the board

column1: There is no governing body that declares any regulations on what constitutes a skateboard or the parts from which it is assembled. Historically
column2: the skateboard has conformed both to contemporary trends and to the ever-evolving array of stunts performed by riders/users
column3: who require a certain functionality from the board. The board shape depends largely upon its desired function. [[Longboard (skateboard)|Longboards]] are a type of skateboard with a longer [[wheelbase]] and larger
column4: softer wheels.

column1: The two main types of skateboards are the longboard and the shortboard. The shape of the board is also important: the skateboard must be concaved to perform tricks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/339215-skateboards-fit-types/ |title=Skateboards: Fit & Types |publisher=LiveStrong |accessdate=June 23
column3: 2012 |url-status=live}}</ref> Longboards are usually faster and are mostly used for cruising and racing
column4: while shortboards are mostly used for doing tricks and riding in skateparks.

column1: Skateboarding started in California in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thoughtco.com/brief-history-of-skateboarding-3002042 |title=Skateboarding: From Wooden Box Boards to Commercial Mainstream |publisher= |access-date=May 6
column3: 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> The first skateboards were made from [[roller skates]] (attached to a board).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teacher.scholastic.com/scholasticnews/indepth/Skateboarding/articles/index.asp?article=history&topic=0 |title=Scholastic News: Skateboarding|website=teacher.scholastic.com |access-date=March 26
column4: 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180403111056/http://teacher.scholastic.com/scholasticnews/indepth/Skateboarding/articles/index.asp?article=history&topic=0 |archive-date=April 3
column5: 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Skateboarding gained in popularity because of surfing: in fact
column6: skateboarding was initially referred to as \"sidewalk surfing\". Initially
column7: skateboards were handmade from wooden boxes and planks by individuals. Companies started manufacturing skateboards in 1959
column8: as the sport became more popular.<ref>{{Citation |title=The mix of sunshine and rebellion is really intoxicating|work=Skate Life|pages=27–77 |publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472900459|doi=10.2307/j.ctv65sw5s.5|year=2010}}</ref> In postwar America
column9: society was carefree with children commonly playing in the streets.<ref>{{Citation |title=The mix of sunshine and rebellion is really intoxicating|work=Skate Life|pages=27–77 |publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472900459|doi=10.2307/j.ctv65sw5s.5|year=2010}}</ref> Boards were also continuing to evolve as companies tried to make them lighter
column10: stronger and improve their performance.

column1: Skateboarding is a very individual activity. Skateboarding still hasn't stopped evolving
column2: and skaters are coming up with new tricks all the time. Since 2000
column3: due to attention in the media and products like skateboarding video games
column4: children's skateboards and commercialization
column5: skateboarding has been pulled into the mainstream. As more interest and money has been invested into skateboarding
column6: more skate parks
column7: and better skateboards have become available. In addition
column8: the continuing interest has motivated skateboarding companies have to keep innovating and inventing new things. In 2020
column9: skateboarding will appear for the first time in the Olympics in Tokyo
column10: Japan.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/2016/08/03/skateboarding-olympics-2020-tokyo-games/| title=Skateboarding Will be in the 2020 Olympics| date=August 3
column11: 2016| access-date=May 6
column12: 2018| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507003554/https://www.highsnobiety.com/2016/08/03/skateboarding-olympics-2020-tokyo-games/| archive-date=May 7
column13: 2018| url-status=live}}</ref>

column1: The following descriptions cover skateboard parts that are most prevalent in popular and modern forms of skateboarding. Many parts exist with exotic or alternative constructions. A traditional complete skateboard consists of the deck (often with griptape applied on top to enhance traction)
column4: bushings
column5: nuts and bolts to fasten the truck and wheel assembly to the bottom of the deck. Older decks also included plastic parts such as side
column6: tail
column7: and nose guards.

column1: [[Image:Skateboard.JPG|thumb|The side of a skateboard]] Modern decks vary in size
column2: but most are {{convert|7|to|10.5|in|cm}} wide. Wider decks can be used for greater stability when skateboarding. Standard skateboard decks are usually between {{convert|28|and|33|in|cm}} long. The underside of the deck can be printed with a design by the manufacturer
column4: or decorated by any other means.

column1: \"Long\" boards are usually over {{convert|36|in|cm}} long. Plastic [[Penny board|\"penny\"]] boards are typically about {{convert|22|in|cm}} long.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/a/umn.edu/historpedia/home/arts-new-ideas/from-skateboard-and-longboard-to-penny-board-fall-2102 |title=From Skateboard and Longboard to Penny Board |date=February 2
column4: 2016 |url-status=live }})</ref> Some larger penny boards over {{convert|27|in|cm}} long are called \"nickel\" boards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rideasf.com/lifestyle/penny-nickel-skateboard-review/ |title=Penny Nickel Skateboard Review |publisher=Ride as F*ck |accessdate=December 15

column1: Mounting hardware is a set of eight 10-32 UNF bolts
column2: usually an [[Allen wrench|Allen]] or [[Phillips (screw head)|Phillips]] head
column3: and matching nylon [[locknut]]s. They are used to attach the trucks (and any type of risers) to the board. Some sets have one different colored bolt to show which side is the nose of the skateboard. Hardware is available in various lengths for mounting trucks with or without risers.

column1: Risers increase the space between the truck and the deck. This allows the truck to twist further without causing wheel bite (when the wheel touches the deck and stops rotating).

Wedges can be used to change the [[steering|turning]] characteristics of a truck.<ref>A guide describing turning characteristics of different Riser/Wedge types {{cite web |url=http://www.randal.com/guides_faq.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 1

Shock pads are made of polyurethane and rubber. They are very similar to risers but vary in the fact that their sole purpose is to cushion the board from the trucks. Since the trucks are metal and the board wood
column2: whenever the board hits the ground after doing a trick
column3: the energy goes through the truck to the board ─ this has caused boards to crack
column4: split
column5: or even break in half
column6: and shock pads were created to prevent this.

column2: are narrow strips of plastic or metal that are attached under the deck lengthwise along the edges. They are used for additional grip for grabs
column3: and to enhance sliding while protecting the deck's graphics at the same time. Rails also provide a more consistent feel for slides
column4: as the slide of a regular skateboard will suffer from the wear of the paint or varnish on the bottom of the board. Although rarely used anymore
column5: they are useful for experienced skaters that are capable of grabs.

column1: Sliptape is a clear piece of self-adhesive plastic that sticks to the underside of a deck. It helps protect the board's graphics and allows the board to slide more easily. Another name for this is everslick.

A lapper is a plastic cover that is fastened to the rear truck and serves to protect the kingpin when grinding. It also prevents hang-ups by providing a smoother transition for the truck when it hits an obstacle or a metal pipe or round bar.
A nose guard is a plastic bumper used to protect the front of a skateboard which was once popular but is now only commonly seen on older board models.
Bolted onto the underside of the tail end of a skateboard
column2: the tail guard (also known as a \"skid plate\") protected the tail end from skid stops and other maneuvers that would otherwise wear away the wood (commonly known as razor tail) and decrease the longevity of the tail. Typically made of plastic
column3: these were widely popular in the '80s but their usage quickly diminished with the arrival of two-tail board designs
column4: which became increasingly popular in the 1990s.

column1: A \"tail devil\" is a sparking device made of flint which is placed either on the tail or nose of the skateboard (or both) to create a sparking effect mainly visible after dark when the tail or nose of the boards scrapes against the ground.
Plastic half tubing that protected the axles of the trucks. In the 1980–85 period
column2: shopping cart handles were cut by some to fit as a makeshift coper.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}

column1: [[Sublimation (phase transition)]] is the transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas phase without passing through an intermediate liquid phase. Sublimation is an endothermic phase transition that occurs at temperatures and pressures below a substance's triple point in its phase diagram. In this case
column2: ink is transferred to a base layer
column4: through heat and pressure
column5: the result is a full color graphic that will not come off as easily as the more common heat transfers. This application is often found with bamboo boards and composite construction longboards where fibreglass can allow for various degrees of flex or stiffness depending on the ride you're looking for
column6: cruising and carving versus slalom and downhill.

column1: While not part of a skateboard
column2: an all in one skateboard tool capable of mounting and removing trucks & wheels and adjusting truck kingpins are commonly sold by [[skate shop]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fasttech.com/products/1921/10062128/9696858-multifunctional-t-type-roller-hex-socket-wrench |title=Multifunctional T-Type Roller Hex Socket Wrench Skateboard Repair Tool |publisher=fasttech.com |accessdate=15 September 2019}}</ref> Some tools include a metal [[Skateboard#Grip_tape|grip-tape]] [[File_(tool)|file]] and can also be used as a [[bottle-opener]]. Tools which can be used for the purpose of re-threading wheel axles
column3: working with bearings and even applying grip-tape have been developed.

column1: '''Glass Animals''' are a [[psychedelic pop]] band formed in [[Oxford]]
column4: and producer Dave Bayley with his bandmates and childhood friends Joe Seaward
column5: Ed Irwin-Singer
column6: and Drew MacFarlane.

column1: Bayley wrote and self-produced both of the band's albums. In 2014
column2: the band released their debut album
column4: which was eventually certified Platinum in the United States. Their second full album
column5: ''[[How to Be a Human Being]]''
column6: received critical acclaim and won in two categories at the 2018 MPG Awards for UK Album of the Year and Self Producing Artist of the Year
column7: as well as a spot on the Mercury Prize shortlist. Outside of his work for Glass Animals
column8: Bayley has written and produced for a number of artists including [[6lack]]
column9: [[Khalid (singer)|Khalid]]
column10: [[Joey Badass]]
column11: [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]]
column12: [[Flume (musician)|Flume]] and [[Denzel Curry]].

column1: The band has become known for their live shows
column3: dance-heavy versions of their songs. They have performed on international TV shows including late night shows with [[Jools Holland]]
column4: [[James Corden]] and [[Jimmy Kimmel]]. Glass Animals has played at a number of venues and festivals around the world including [[Radio City Music Hall]]
column5: Red Rocks
column6: Brixton Academy
column7: [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]]
column8: [[Lollapalooza]]
column9: Glastonbury
column10: Latitude
column11: Reading and Leeds
column12: and Falls.

column1: The band released their debut EP
column4: which included the single \"Cocoa Hooves\". The EP was released on independent label Kaya Kaya Records
column5: a subsidiary and imprint of [[XL Recordings]] (part of the [[Beggars Group]] of labels). At the time
column6: lead singer and guitarist Dave Bayley was attending medical school at King's College
column7: London but left after [[Adele]]'s producer [[Paul Epworth]] saw Glass Animals performing in London and signed them to his label Wolf Tone.

column2: the band released ''Black Mambo / Exxus EP'' in Europe
column3: and ''Glass Animals EP'' in the US. The digital release of the track \"Black Mambo\" brought the band their first attention through online reviews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hypem.com/track/1wegy/Glass+Animals+-+Black+Mambo|title=Black Mambo|website=Hype Machine|accessdate=15 November 2019}}</ref> The ''Glass Animals'' EP also saw the band collaborating with Jean Deaux
column4: a soulful hip-hop teenager from Chicago
column5: on a song titled \"Woozy\".

column2: the band made their first visit to the USA
column3: performing at ''[[South by Southwest]]'' in Austin
column4: Texas. They released three more singles: \"Pools\"
column5: \"Gooey\"
column6: and \"Hazey\"
column7: along with a collaboration with Argentine singer-songwriter and producer [[Tei Shi]].{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}

column1: All five singles were included on the band's debut album
column3: which was released on 6 June 2014. The band performed the single \"Gooey\" on ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]''<ref>{{Cite web|title = Watch Glass Animals Get \"Gooey\" Again on Late Night With Seth Meyers {{!}} The Lefort Report|url = http://www.thelefortreport.com/blog/2014-10/watch-glass-animals-get-gooey-again-on-late-night-with-seth-meyers/|website = www.thelefortreport.com|access-date = 21 January 2016}}</ref> in 2014
column4: and again on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman|The Late Show]]'' with [[David Letterman]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Watch Glass Animals play 'Gooey' on Letterman|url = http://diymag.com/2015/02/26/watch-glass-animals-play-gooey-on-letterman|website = DIY|access-date = 21 January 2016}}</ref> on 24 February 2015
column5: and toured extensively after ''Zaba''
column6: visiting both hemispheres and played over 130 shows in 2015 alone. Their October 2015 US tour included two sold out shows at The Wiltern in LA and sold out shows across America including T5 in NYC
column7: The Riverside in Milwaukee
column8: and the [[Midland Theatre]] in [[Kansas City]].

column1: A collaboration with American rapper [[Joey Badass|Joey Bada$$]]
column3: was released on 6 October 2015. The idea for the song was apparently sparked during a randomly shared studio session. Following the collaboration
column4: Bayley remarked that he would be interested in working with Joey again in the future.

column1: Bayley also worked with DJ Dahi
column2: resulting in a writing cut on the track \"The Middle Finger\" on Wale's ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' number one album
column3: ''[[The Album About Nothing]]'' in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Wale - The Middle Finger Lyrics {{!}} Genius Lyrics |url= https://genius.com/Wale-the-middle-finger-lyrics |website= genius.com}}</ref>

column1: === 2016–2018: ''How to Be a Human Being'' and tour ===

column2: drummer Joe Seaward was seriously injured when he was hit by a [[lorry]] while cycling in [[Dublin]]. column5: peaking at number one.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/08/glass-animals-track-by-track-guide-to-how-to-be-a.html|title=Glass Animals: Track-By-Track Guide to How To Be A Human Being|newspaper=pastemagazine.com|access-date=2017-01-16}}</ref> A music video for the song was released on 7 June 2016. The band also created a website based on the character from \"Life Itself\".

column1: The full album ''How to Be a Human Being'' was released on 26 August 2016 by Wolf Tone and [[Caroline International]] in Europe
column2: and [[Harvest Records]] in the United States. The album received critical acclaim for its \"sense of wonder\" and \"immediate impression\"
column3: though it was also met with some mixed reactions
column4: for critics felt that it was somewhat premature. They played [[St Jerome's Laneway Festival|Laneway Festivals]] in six different cities (Singapore
column5: Sydney
column6: and Auckland
column7: among others). During their time in Australia

column9: \"Life Itself\"

column11: respectively—came in at 38
column12: 63 and 98 on [[Triple J Hottest 100
column13: 2016|Triple J's Hottest 100]].{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}

column2: drummer Joe Seaward was seriously injured when he was hit by a [[lorry]] while cycling in [[Dublin]]. Joe's accident and recovery resulted in the band canceling their remaining tour dates for rest of the year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Glass Animals Cancel Tour After Drummer Hit by Truck {{!}} Pitchfork |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/glass-animals-cancel-tour-after-drummer-hit-by-truck/ |website=pitchfork.com |accessdate=15 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
the band has released two singles; one in late 2019 named \"Tokyo Drifting\"

The '''geography of Texas''' is diverse and large. Occupying about 7% of the total water and land area of the U.S.,<ref name=\Tx Almanac Area\">{{cite web|url= http://texasalmanac.com/topics/environment/environment|title= Texas Almanac|accessdate= 2016-06-25}}</ref> it is the second largest state after [[Alaska]]
column5: and is the southernmost part of the [[Great Plains]]
column6: which end in the south against the folded [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] of [[Mexico]]. [[Texas]] is in the [[South Central United States]] of America
column7: and is considered to form part of the [[U.S. Southern States|U.S. South]] and also part of the [[Southwest United States|U.S. Southwest]].<ref>{{cite web | url =

column1: http://www.texasmonthly.com/the-daily-post/is-texas-southern-western-or-truly-a-lone-star/ | website = [[Texas Monthly]] | title = Is Texas Southern
column3: or Truly a Lone Star? | last = Nova Lomax | first = John | date = M&777&&arch 3
column4: 2015 | accessdate = September 6

column2: the state is generally divided into [[North Texas]]
column4: [[Central Texas]]
column5: [[South Texas]]
column6: [[West Texas]] (and sometimes the [[Texas Panhandle|Panhandle]])
column7: but according to the ''[[Texas Almanac]]''
column8: Texas has four major physical regions: Gulf Coastal Plains
column9: Interior Lowlands
column10: Great Plains
column11: and Basin and Range Province. This has been cited as the difference between [[human geography]] and [[physical geography]]
column12: although the fact that Texas was granted [[Texas divisionism|the prerogative to divide into as many as five U.S. states]] may be a historical motive for Texans defining their state as containing exactly five regions.<ref name=\"State division\">{{cite web|url= http://www.texasescapes.com/MikeCoxTexasTales/211Texas-County-Seats-and-Counties-Name-Confusion.htm| title= Texas Escapes.com|accessdate= 2006-07-15}}</ref>

column1: Some [[List of geographical regions in Texas|regions in Texas]] are more associated with the Southeast than the Southwest (primarily East Texas
column4: while other regions share more similarities with the Southwest (primarily far West Texas and lower South Texas). The [[Salient (geography)|upper Panhandle]] is considered by many to have more in common with parts of the [[Midwestern United States|plains Midwest]] than either the South or Southwest. The size of Texas prohibits easy categorization of the entire state wholly in any recognized region of the United States
column5: and even [[cultural diversity]] among regions of the state make it difficult to treat Texas as a region in its own right.

column1: [[File:Texas Köppen.svg|thumb|300px|[[Köppen climate classification]] types of Texas]]
[[Image:Texas Rivers 1895.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[List of Texas rivers|Texas rivers]] map showing [[Randolph B. Marcy|Captain Marcy]]'s route though Texas in 1854.]]

column3: and [[Subtropics|Modified Marine]] are the three major [[Climate|climatic types]] of Texas
column4: with no distinguishable boundaries. Modified Marine
column5: or subtropical
column6: dominates the majority of the state.<ref name=\"Tx A&M Climate\">{{cite web|url= http://www.met.tamu.edu/osc/TXclimat.htm|title= The Office of the State Climatologist|accessdate= 2006-07-14|archivedate = 2006-07-06 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060706024532/http://www.met.tamu.edu/osc/TXclimat.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->}}</ref> Texas has an annual [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] range from {{convert|60.57|in|mm}} in [[Jasper County
column7: Texas|Jasper County]]
column8: East Texas
column9: to {{convert|9.43|in|mm}} in [[El Paso
column10: Texas|El Paso]]. The record high of {{convert|120|°F|°C|abbr=on|lk=on}} was reached at [[Seymour
column11: Texas|Seymour]] on August 12
column13: and [[Monahans
column14: Texas|Monahans]] on June 28
column15: 1994. The low also ties at {{convert|-23|°F|°C|abbr=on|lk=on}} in [[Tulia
column19: Texas|Seminole]] on February 8
column20: 1933.<ref name=\"Tx Almanac Climate\">{{cite web|url= https://texasalmanac.com/topics/facts-profile|title= Tx Almanac|accessdate= 2018-07-03}}</ref>

column1: Texas covers a total area of {{convert|268581|sqmi|km2|0}}. The longest straight-line distance is from the northwest corner of the panhandle to the [[Rio Grande]] river just below [[Brownsville
column3: {{convert|801|mi|km|0}}.<ref name=\"Tx Almanac Area\"/> The width west-to-east
column4: from [[El Paso
column5: Texas|El Paso]] to [[Orange
column6: Texas]]
column7: is {{convert|862|mi|km|0}}. The largest continental state is so expansive that El Paso
column8: in the western corner of the state
column9: is closer to [[San Diego|San Diego
column10: California]]
column11: than to the [[Houston]] and [[Beaumont
column12: Texas|Beaumont]] area
column13: near the Louisiana state line; while [[Orange
column14: Texas|Orange]]
column18: than it is to El Paso. [[Texarkana
column19: Texas|Texarkana]]
column20: in the northeastern corner of the state
column21: is about the same distance from [[Chicago|Chicago
column23: as it is from El Paso
column26: in the northwestern corner of the state
column27: is closer to the [[List of capitals in the United States|state capitals]] of [[Topeka
column37: its own state capital.<ref name=\"Stats\">{{cite web|url= http://www.statemaster.com/state/TX-texas/geo-geography|title= StateMaster|accessdate= 2006-07-11}}</ref>

column1: The geographic center of Texas is about {{convert|15|mi|km}} northeast of [[Brady
column4: at {{convert|8749|ft|m|1}} above [[sea level]]
column5: is the highest point in Texas
column6: the lowest being sea level where Texas meets the [[Gulf of Mexico]].<ref name=\"Netstate Tx\">{{cite web|url= http://www.netstate.com/states/geography/tx_geography.htm|title= Netstate|accessdate= 2006-07-11}}</ref> Texas has five state forests and 120 [[state park]]s for a total over {{convert|605000|acre|km2}}.<ref name=\"About.com\">{{cite web|url=http://geography.about.com/gi/dynamic/offsite.htm?site=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0108277.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101194550/http://geography.about.com/gi/dynamic/offsite.htm?site=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0108277.html|title=About.com |accessdate=2006-07-11 |url-status=dead |archivedate=2013-01-01}}</ref> There are 3
column7: 700 named streams and 15 major river systems flowing through {{convert|191000|mi|km}} of Texas
column8: supporting over 212 [[Reservoir (water)|reservoirs]].<ref name=\"Rivers\">{{cite web|url= http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/landwater/water/habitats/rivers/|title=Tx Parks and Wildlife|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref>

column4: regional classification becomes problematic with differences in soils
column5: topography
column6: geology
column7: rainfall
column8: and plant and animal communities.<ref name=\"Tx eco regions\">{{cite web|url=http://www.texasep.org/html/lnd/lnd_1reg.html |title=Tx Environmental Profiles |accessdate=2006-07-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603175718/http://www.texasep.org/html/lnd/lnd_1reg.html |archivedate=2008-06-03 }}</ref>

column1: Much of the {{Convert|367|mi|km|adj=on}} Gulf coastline of Texas is paralleled by the [[Texas barrier islands]]
column2: many of which enclose a [[Estuaries of Texas|series of estuaries]] where the state's rivers mix with water from the Gulf of Mexico. These water bodies include some of the largest and most ecologically productive coastal estuaries in the United States and contribute significantly to the ecological and economic resources of Texas.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Bays & Estuaries|website=[[Texas Water Development Board]]|url=https://www.twdb.texas.gov/surfacewater/bays/index.asp|accessdate=March 8

column1: The [[Gulf Coastal Plains]] extends from the Gulf of Mexico inland to the [[Balcones Fault]] and the [[Cross Timbers|Eastern Cross Timbers]]. This large area stretches from the cities of [[Paris
column3: Texas|Del Rio]] but shows a large variety in vegetation. Ranging from {{Convert|20|to|58|in|mm}} of annual rainfall
column4: this is a nearly level
column5: drained plain dissected by streams and rivers flowing into coastal estuaries and [[marsh]]es. Windblown sands and dunes
column6: grasslands
column7: oak mottes and salt marshes make up the seaward areas.<ref name=\"Regions\">{{cite web |url=http://www.lone-star.net/mall/txtrails/regions.htm |title= LoneStarInternet|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref> [[National Park]]s include [[Big Thicket National Preserve]]
column8: [[Padre Island National Seashore]] and the [[Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site]].<ref name=\"NatParks\">{{cite web |url=http://www.texasep.org/html/lnd/lnd_5pub.html |title= Tx Environmental Profiles|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref>

column1: [[Image:Caprock Escarpment.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Looking north at the Caprock Escarpment.]]
The North Central Plains are bounded by the [[Caprock Escarpment]] to the west
column3: and the [[Cross Timbers#29b: Eastern Cross Timbers|Eastern Cross Timbers]] to the east. This area includes the North Central Plains around the cities of [[Abilene
column4: Texas|Abilene]] and [[Wichita Falls
column5: Texas|Wichita Falls]]
column6: the [[Cross Timbers#29c: Western Cross Timbers|Western Cross Timbers]] to the west of [[Fort Worth
column7: Texas|Fort Worth]]
column8: the [[Cross Timbers#29d: Grand Prairie|Grand Prairie]]
column9: and the Eastern Cross Timbers to the east of [[Dallas]]. With about {{convert|35|to|50|in|mm}} annual rainfall
column10: gently rolling to hilly forested land is part of a larger pine-hardwood forest of [[oak]]s
column11: [[Hickory|hickories]]
column12: [[elm]] and [[Nyssa sylvatica|gum]] trees.<ref name=\"Regions\"/> Soils vary from coarse sands to tight clays or shet rock clays and [[shale]]s.<ref name=\"Rolling Plains\">{{cite web|url=http://texasprairie.org/index.php/npat_prairies/region_info/the_rolling_plains_region|title=The Rolling Plains Region|accessdate=2013-08-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022042152/http://texasprairie.org/index.php/npat_prairies/region_info/the_rolling_plains_region/|archive-date=2013-10-22|url-status=dead}}</ref>

column4: Toyah Basin
column5: and the [[Llano Uplift]]. It is bordered on the east by the [[Caprock Escarpment]] in the panhandle and by the [[Balcones Fault]] to the southeast. Cities in this region include [[Midland
column6: Texas|Midland]] and [[Odessa
column7: Texas|Odessa]]
column8: [[Lubbock
column9: Texas|Lubbock]]
column10: and [[Amarillo
column11: Texas|Amarillo]]. The [[Texas Hill Country|Hill Country]] is a popular name for the area of hills along the [[Balcones Escarpment]] and is a transitional area between the [[Great Plains]] and the [[Gulf Coastal Plains]]. With about {{convert|15|to|31|in|mm}} annual rainfall
column12: the southern end of the Great Plains are gently rolling plains of shrub and grassland
column13: and home to the dramatic [[Caprock Canyons State Park and Trailway|Caprock Canyons]] and [[Palo Duro Canyon]] state parks.<ref name=\"Regions\"/> The largest concentration of [[playa lake]]s in the world (nearly 22
column14: 000) is on the Southern High Plains of Texas and Eastern [[New Mexico]].

column1: Texas's [[Texas blackland prairies|blackland prairies]] were some of the first areas farmed in Texas. Highly expansive [[clay]]s with characteristic dark coloration
column4: 000 km²) extending from north of Dallas south to San Antonio. The Professional Soil Scientists Association of Texas has recommended to the State Legislature that the [[Houston]] Black series be designated the State soil. The series was established in 1902.<ref name=\"Soil\">{{cite web|url=ftp://ftp-fc.sc.egov.usda.gov/NSSC/StateSoil_Profiles/tx_soil.pdf |title=USDA Houston Black |accessdate=2006-07-14 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> National Parks in this area are the [[Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park]] and the [[San Antonio Missions National Historical Park]].<ref name=\"NatParks\"/>

column1: [[Image:Big Bend Rio Grande.jpg|thumb|right|[[Rio Grande Valley]] in the [[Big Bend (Texas)|Big Bend]] area]]
The [[Trans-Pecos]] Natural Region has less than {{convert|12|in|mm}} annual rainfall. The most complex Natural Region
column4: desert valleys
column5: wooded mountain slopes and desert grasslands. The [[Basin and Range Province]] is in West Texas
column6: west of the [[Pecos River]]
column7: beginning with the [[Davis Mountains]] on the east and the [[Rio Grande]] to its west and south. The Trans-Pecos region is the only part of Texas regarded as mountainous and includes seven named peaks in elevation greater than {{convert|8000|ft|m}}. This region includes sand hills
column8: desert valleys
column9: wooded mountain slopes and desert grasslands.<ref name=\"Regions\"/> The vegetation diversity includes at least 268 [[grass]] species and 447 species of [[woody plant]]s.<ref name=\"Trans-Pecos\">{{cite web|url= http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/landwater/land/habitats/trans_pecos/|title= Tx Parks and Wildlife|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref> National Parks include the [[Amistad National Recreation Area]]

column13: [[Guadalupe Mountains National Park]]
column14: and the [[Rio Grande Wild and Scenic River]].<ref name=\"NatParks\"/> This area is part of the [[Chihuahuan Desert]].

column2: with East Texas underlain by a [[Cretaceous]] and younger sequence of sediments
column3: the trace of ancient shorelines east and south until the [[active continental margin]] of the [[Gulf of Mexico]] is met.{{citation needed|date=December 2019}} This sequence is built atop the subsided crest of the [[Appalachian Mountains]]–[[Ouachita Mountains]]–[[Marathon Uplift|Marathon Mountains]] zone of [[Pennsylvanian (geology)|Pennsylvanian]] [[continental collision]]
column4: which [[post-orogenic collapse|collapsed]] when [[rifting]] in [[Jurassic]] time opened the Gulf of Mexico. West from this [[orogeny|orogenic]] crest

column11: and [[Oligocene]] [[volcanic]] rocks are found in far west Texas
column12: in the [[Big Bend
column13: Texas|Big Bend]] area. A blanket of [[Miocene]] sediments known as the [[Ogallala formation]] in the western high plains region is an important [[aquifer]]. Texas has no active or dormant volcanoes and few earthquakes
column14: being situated far from an active [[plate tectonic]] boundary. The Big Bend area is the most seismically active; however
column15: the area is sparsely populated and suffers minimal damages and injuries
column16: and no known fatalities have been attributed to a Texas earthquake.

column1: *Deposits of [[graphite]] occur in the Llano region and was previously produced in Burnet County.
*Bat [[guano]] occurs in numerous caverns in the Edwards Plateau and in the Trans-Pecos region and to a more limited extent in Central Texas.
*[[Gypsum]] is extensively developed in Texas where the main occurrences are in the [[Permian Basin (North America)|Permian Basin]]

column1: *Texas is the leading producer of [[helium]] solely from the Cliffside gas field near Amarillo.
*Deposits of [[iron ore]] are present in northeastern Texas as well as several in Central Texas.

*Elements of the [[Lanthanide]] series are commonly termed rare-earth elements. Several of the rare earths have anomalous concentrations in the [[rhyolitic]] and related igneous rocks in the Trans-Pecos area of Texas. A deposit containing several rare-earth minerals was exposed at Barringer Hill in Llano County before it was covered by the waters of Lake Buchanan.

*[[Sand]]s used for industrial purposes commonly have been found in the Texas Coastal Plains
column4: and Central Texas; and sand mines have opened in the Shinnery (dunes) ecosystem of northern West Texas and the eastern part of the West Wingtip.

column1: *The discovery of [[silver]] in Texas has been credited by some to Franciscans who discovered and operated mines near El Paso about 1680. Documented silver production started in the late 1880s at the Presidio Mine

The '''geography of Texas''' is diverse and large. Occupying about 7% of the total water and land area of the U.S.,<ref name=\Tx Almanac Area\">{{cite web|url= http://texasalmanac.com/topics/environment/environment|title= Texas Almanac|accessdate= 2016-06-25}}</ref> it is the second largest state after [[Alaska]]
column3: and is the southernmost part of the [[Great Plains]]
column4: which end in the south against the folded [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] of [[Mexico]]. [[Texas]] is in the [[South Central United States]] of America
column5: and is considered to form part of the [[U.S. Southern States|U.S. South]] and also part of the [[Southwest United States|U.S. Southwest]].<ref>{{cite web | url =

column1: http://www.texasmonthly.com/the-daily-post/is-texas-southern-western-or-truly-a-lone-star/ | website = [[Texas Monthly]] | title = Is Texas Southern
column3: or Truly a Lone Star? | last = Nova Lomax | first = John | date = M&777&&arch 3
column4: 2015 | accessdate = September 6

column2: the state is generally divided into [[North Texas]]
column4: [[Central Texas]]
column5: [[South Texas]]
column6: [[West Texas]] (and sometimes the [[Texas Panhandle|Panhandle]])
column7: but according to the ''[[Texas Almanac]]''
column8: Texas has four major physical regions: Gulf Coastal Plains
column9: Interior Lowlands
column10: Great Plains
column11: and Basin and Range Province. This has been cited as the difference between [[human geography]] and [[physical geography]]
column12: although the fact that Texas was granted [[Texas divisionism|the prerogative to divide into as many as five U.S. states]] may be a historical motive for Texans defining their state as containing exactly five regions.<ref name=\"State division\">{{cite web|url= http://www.texasescapes.com/MikeCoxTexasTales/211Texas-County-Seats-and-Counties-Name-Confusion.htm| title= Texas Escapes.com|accessdate= 2006-07-15}}</ref>

column1: Some [[List of geographical regions in Texas|regions in Texas]] are more associated with the Southeast than the Southwest (primarily East Texas
column4: while other regions share more similarities with the Southwest (primarily far West Texas and lower South Texas). The [[Salient (geography)|upper Panhandle]] is considered by many to have more in common with parts of the [[Midwestern United States|plains Midwest]] than either the South or Southwest. The size of Texas prohibits easy categorization of the entire state wholly in any recognized region of the United States
column5: and even [[cultural diversity]] among regions of the state make it difficult to treat Texas as a region in its own right.

column1: Much of the {{Convert|367|mi|km|adj=on}} Gulf coastline of Texas is paralleled by the [[Texas barrier islands]]
column2: many of which enclose a [[Estuaries of Texas|series of estuaries]] where the state's rivers mix with water from the Gulf of Mexico. These water bodies include some of the largest and most ecologically productive coastal estuaries in the United States and contribute significantly to the ecological and economic resources of Texas.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Bays & Estuaries|website=[[Texas Water Development Board]]|url=https://www.twdb.texas.gov/surfacewater/bays/index.asp|accessdate=March 8

column1: The [[Gulf Coastal Plains]] extends from the Gulf of Mexico inland to the [[Balcones Fault]] and the [[Cross Timbers|Eastern Cross Timbers]]. This large area stretches from the cities of [[Paris
column3: Texas|Del Rio]] but shows a large variety in vegetation. Ranging from {{Convert|20|to|58|in|mm}} of annual rainfall
column4: this is a nearly level
column5: drained plain dissected by streams and rivers flowing into coastal estuaries and [[marsh]]es. Windblown sands and dunes
column6: grasslands
column7: oak mottes and salt marshes make up the seaward areas.<ref name=\"Regions\">{{cite web |url=http://www.lone-star.net/mall/txtrails/regions.htm |title= LoneStarInternet|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref> [[National Park]]s include [[Big Thicket National Preserve]]
column8: [[Padre Island National Seashore]] and the [[Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site]].<ref name=\"NatParks\">{{cite web |url=http://www.texasep.org/html/lnd/lnd_5pub.html |title= Tx Environmental Profiles|accessdate= 2006-07-14}}</ref>

column1: [[Image:Caprock Escarpment.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Looking north at the Caprock Escarpment.]]
The North Central Plains are bounded by the [[Caprock Escarpment]] to the west
column3: and the [[Cross Timbers#29b: Eastern Cross Timbers|Eastern Cross Timbers]] to the east. This area includes the North Central Plains around the cities of [[Abilene
column4: Texas|Abilene]] and [[Wichita Falls
column5: Texas|Wichita Falls]]
column6: the [[Cross Timbers#29c: Western Cross Timbers|Western Cross Timbers]] to the west of [[Fort Worth
column7: Texas|Fort Worth]]
column8: the [[Cross Timbers#29d: Grand Prairie|Grand Prairie]]
column9: and the Eastern Cross Timbers to the east of [[Dallas]]. With about {{convert|35|to|50|in|mm}} annual rainfall
column10: gently rolling to hilly forested land is part of a larger pine-hardwood forest of [[oak]]s
column11: [[Hickory|hickories]]
column12: [[elm]] and [[Nyssa sylvatica|gum]] trees.<ref name=\"Regions\"/> Soils vary from coarse sands to tight clays or shet rock clays and [[shale]]s.<ref name=\"Rolling Plains\">{{cite web|url=http://texasprairie.org/index.php/npat_prairies/region_info/the_rolling_plains_region|title=The Rolling Plains Region|accessdate=2013-08-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022042152/http://texasprairie.org/index.php/npat_prairies/region_info/the_rolling_plains_region/|archive-date=2013-10-22|url-status=dead}}</ref>

column4: Toyah Basin
column5: and the [[Llano Uplift]]. It is bordered on the east by the [[Caprock Escarpment]] in the panhandle and by the [[Balcones Fault]] to the southeast. Cities in this region include [[Midland
column6: Texas|Midland]] and [[Odessa
column7: Texas|Odessa]]
column8: [[Lubbock
column9: Texas|Lubbock]]
column10: and [[Amarillo
column11: Texas|Amarillo]]. The [[Texas Hill Country|Hill Country]] is a popular name for the area of hills along the [[Balcones Escarpment]] and is a transitional area between the [[Great Plains]] and the [[Gulf Coastal Plains]]. With about {{convert|15|to|31|in|mm}} annual rainfall
column12: the southern end of the Great Plains are gently rolling plains of shrub and grassland
column13: and home to the dramatic [[Caprock Canyons State Park and Trailway|Caprock Canyons]] and [[Palo Duro Canyon]] state parks.<ref name=\"Regions\"/> The largest concentration of [[playa lake]]s in the world (nearly 22
column14: 000) is on the Southern High Plains of Texas and Eastern [[New Mexico]].

column1: Texas's [[Texas blackland prairies|blackland prairies]] were some of the first areas farmed in Texas. Highly expansive [[clay]]s with characteristic dark coloration
column4: 000 km²) extending from north of Dallas south to San Antonio. The Professional Soil Scientists Association of Texas has recommended to the State Legislature that the [[Houston]] Black series be designated the State soil. The series was established in 1902.<ref name=\"Soil\">{{cite web|url=ftp://ftp-fc.sc.egov.usda.gov/NSSC/StateSoil_Profiles/tx_soil.pdf |title=USDA Houston Black |accessdate=2006-07-14 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> National Parks in this area are the [[Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park]] and the [[San Antonio Missions National Historical Park]].<ref name=\"NatParks\"/>
