{{Use dmy dates|date = January 2019}} {{Use American English|date = January 2019}} {{Short description|Scientific instrument of the InSight Mars lander}} {{Infobox spacecraft instrument | Name = Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package {{nowrap|(HP3)}} | Image = Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package (HP3) (cropped).png | Caption = Artist's impression of HP3 on the surface of Mars | Operator = [[NASA]] | Manufacturer = [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR) | Type = [[radiometer|infrared radiometer]],
thermal conductivity sensor | Function = [[Geology of Mars|Geophysics of Mars]] | Mission_Duration = 2 years on Mars (planned) | Began = Landing: 26 November 2018 | Ceased = | Webpage = {{url|https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/instruments/hp3/}} | Mass = {{convert|3|kg|abbr=on}} | Power_consumption = 2 [[watt]]s | Data_Rate = | Spacecraft = ''[[InSight]]'' Mars lander | SC_Operator = NASA | Launch = {{start-date|5 May 2018, 11:05}} [[UTC]] | Rocket = [[Atlas V]] 401{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1312/19insight/ |title=Mars lander to launch from California on Atlas 5 in 2016 |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=20 December 2013}}

column1: | Launch_Site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 3|SLC-3E]]<ref name=\"Atlas V\"/>

The '''Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package''' ('''HP<sup>3</sup>''') is a science payload onboard the ''[[InSight]]'' lander that features instruments to study the heat flow and other thermal properties of [[Mars]]. One of the instruments
column3: is designed to penetrate {{Cvt|5|m}} below Mars' surface. In March 2019
column4: the mole successfully burrowed a few centimeters
column5: but then became unable to continue. In the following year further efforts were made to resolve the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/307933-nasa-uses-insights-robotic-arm-to-push-heat-probe-into-mars|title=NASA Uses InSight's Robotic Arm to Push Heat Probe Into Mars - ExtremeTech|website=www.extremetech.com|access-date=2020-03-22}}</ref>

column1: HP<sup>3</sup> was provided by the [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR). The hammering mechanism inside the mole was designed by the Polish company [[Astronika]] and the Space Research Centre of the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]] under contract and in cooperation with DLR.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://scienceinpoland.pap.pl/en/news/news
column3: polish-kret-will-fly-to-mars.html |title=Polish Kret will fly to Mars |work=Science in Poland |access-date=2018-05-05 |language=en}}</ref>

column1: The Principal Investigator is Tilman Spohn from the German Aerospace Center.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3}}

The mission aims to understand the origin and diversity of [[terrestrial planet]]s.<ref name=\"octoberpres\">{{cite conference |url=https://mepag.jpl.nasa.gov/meeting/2012-10/10_2012-1004_MEPAG.pdf |title=InSight – Geophysical Mission to Mars |conference=26th Mars Exploration Program Analysis Group Meeting. 4 October 2012. Monrovia
column2: California. |first=W. Bruce |last=Banerdt |date=2012}}</ref> Information from the HP<sup>3</sup> heat flow package is expected to reveal whether Mars and Earth formed from the same material
column3: and determine how active the interior of Mars is today.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3|flow}}<ref name=\"nasapr20120820\">{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mars/news/insight20120820.html |title=New Insight on Mars Expected From new NASA Mission |publisher=NASA |first=D. C. |last=Agle |date=20 August 2012}}</ref> Additional science goals include determining the thickness of Mars' crust
column4: the composition of its mantle
column5: and thermal characteristics of the interior
column6: such as the temperature gradient and heat flux.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/science/goals|title=Goals {{!}} Science|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2019-09-03}}</ref>

column2: the mission will estimate the size of Mars' [[Planetary core|core]] and whether the core is liquid or solid.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.universetoday.com/93843/nasas-proposed-insight-lander-would-peer-to-the-center-of-mars-in-2016/ |title=NASAs Proposed 'InSight' Lander would Peer to the Center of Mars in 2016 |work=Universe Today |first=Ken |last=Kremer |date=2 March 2012 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> The vibrations generated by the mole will be monitored by SEIS to learn about the local subsurface.<ref name=\"mars.nasa.gov\">{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/timeline/surface-operations|title=Surface Operations {{!}} Timeline|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2018-12-24}}</ref>
HP<sup>3</sup> includes an infrared [[radiometer]] (HP3-RAD) mounted to the landing platform
column3: also contributed by DLR.<ref name=\"Banerdt20130307\">{{cite conference |url=http://sites.nationalacademies.org/cs/groups/ssbsite/documents/webpage/ssb_086912.pdf |title=InSight: A Geophysical Mission to a Terrestrial Planet Interior |conference=Committee on Astrobiology and Planetary Science. 6–8 March 2013. Washington
column4: D.C. |first=W. Bruce |last=Banerdt |date=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"in-depth\">{{Cite news |url=https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/insight/in-depth/ |title=InSight: In Depth |work=Solar System Exploration |publisher=NASA |access-date=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=\"Grott2017\">{{cite journal |title=The MASCOT Radiometer MARA for the Hayabusa 2 Mission |journal=Space Science Reviews |first1=M. |last1=Grott |first2=J. |last2=Knollenberg |first3=B. |last3=Borgs |first4=F. |last4=Hänschke |first5=E. |last5=Kessler |first6=J. |last6=Helbert |first7=A. |last7=Maturilli |first8=N. |last8=Müller |display-authors=1 |volume=208 |issue=1–4 |pages=413–431 |date=July 2017 |doi=10.1007/s11214-016-0272-1 |bibcode=2017SSRv..208..413G}}</ref>

column1: {{stack|[[File:InSight's HP3 instrument diagram.png|thumb|upright=1.2|Diagram showing the components of HP<sup>3</sup>]]}}

The HP<sup>3</sup> heat flow probe is made up of the following subsystems:<ref name=\"DLR\">{{cite web |title=HP3 heat flow probe |url=https://www.dlr.de/dlr/en/desktopdefault.aspx/tabid-11038/1865_read-27097/ |website=DLR Portal |accessdate=2 September 2019 |language=en}}</ref>
**'''Engineering tether''' (ET) to communicate between the support structure to the lander
**'''Science tether''' (TEM-P) a [[Flexible electronics|flex PCB]] with 14 platinum [[Resistance thermometer|RTDs]] for measuring thermal properties of the regolith.
**'''Tether length monitor''' (TLM) optical length meter for measuring the deployed length of the science tether
* '''Mole penetrometer''' for burrowing beneath the surface
** '''STATIL''' [[tiltmeter]] for determining orientation and direction of the mole.
[[File:InSight's HP3 instrument Image-36-full.jpg|thumb|HP<sup>3</sup> before launch. Left to right:  mole
column4: and engineering tether.]]

column1: HP<sup>3</sup> was conceived by Gromov V. V. et al. in 1997
column2: <ref name='Hammering mechanism'/><ref>Gromov V.V. et al.: ''The mobile penetrometer
column3: a \"mole\" for sub-surface soil investigation.'' In Proc. of 7th European Space Mechanisms and Tribology Symposium. 1997.</ref> and first flown as the PLUTO instrument on the failed 2003 ''[[Beagle 2]]'' Mars lander mission.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/> HP<sup>3</sup> evolved further and it was proposed in 2001 for a mission to [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]
column4: <ref name='proposals'>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/223287921_A_heat_flow_and_physical_properties_package_for_the_surface_of_Mercury A heat flow and physical properties package for the surface of Mercury].  Tilman Spohn
column5: Karsten Seiferlin. ''Planetary and Space Science'' 49(14-15):1571-1577 December 2001. {{doi|10.1016/S0032-0633(01)00094-0}}</ref> in 2009 to the [[European Space Agency]] as part of the Humboldt payload onboard the [[ExoMars]] lander
column6: <ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009EGUGA..1113520K HP3 on ExoMars]. Krause
column7: C.; Izzo
column8: M.; Re
column9: E.; Mehls
column10: C.; Richter
column11: L.; Coste
column12: P. EGU General Assembly 2009
column13: held 19–24 April 2009 in Vienna
column14: Austria.</ref><ref name='proposals'/> in 2010 for a mission to the Moon
column15: <ref>[https://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lunargeo2010/pdf/3016.pdf Measuring heat flow on the Moon — The Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package HP3.] (PDF) T. Spohn
column19: and the HP3 instrument team. Ground-based Geophysics on the Moon (2010). Lunar and Planetary Institute
column20: conference 2010.</ref> and in 2011 it was proposed to NASA's [[Discovery Program]] as a payload for ''InSight'' Mars lander
column21: known at that time as GEMS (Geophysical Monitoring Station).<ref name=\"flow\">{{cite conference |url=http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EPSC-DPS2011/EPSC-DPS2011-379-1.pdf |title=Measuring Heat Flow on Mars: The Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package on GEMS |conference=EPSC-DPS Joint Meeting 2011. 2–7 October 2011. Nantes
column22: France. |first1=M. |last1=Grott |first2=T. |last2=Spohn |first3=W. B. |last3=Banerdt |first4=S. |last4=Smrekar |first5=T. L. |last5=Hudson |display-authors=etal |date=October 2011 |bibcode=2011epsc.conf..379G |id=EPSC-DPS2011-379-1}}</ref> ''InSight'' was launched on 5 May 2018 and landed on 26 November 2018.

column1: The mole is described as a \"self-hammering nail\" and was designed to burrow below the Martian surface while trailing a tether with embedded heaters and temperature sensors. The goal is to measure the thermal properties of Mars' interior
column2: and thus reveal unique information about the planet's geologic history.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'>[http://esmats.eu/amspapers/pastpapers/pdfs/2016/grygorczuk2.pdf Hammering Mechanism for HP3 Experiment (InSight)]. (PDF) Jerzy Grygorczuk1
column4: Bartosz Kędziora1
column5: Maciej Borys
column6: Rafał Przybyła1
column7: Tomasz Kuciński1
column8: Maciej Ossowski
column9: Wojciech Konior
column10: Olaf Krömer
column11: Tilman Spohn
column12: Marta Tokarz and Mateusz Białek. ''European Space Mechanisms and Tribology Symposium''; 2016.</ref>

column1: The burrowing mole is a pointed cylinder with a smooth outer surface approximately {{cvt|35|cm}} in length and {{cvt|3.5|cm}} in diameter. It contains a heater to determine thermal conductivity during descent
column2: and it trails a tether equipped with precise heat sensors placed at {{convert|10|cm|abbr=on}} intervals to measure the temperature profile of the subsurface.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3}}

column1: The mole penetrator unit is designed to be placed near the lander in an area about 3-m long and 2-m wide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.seis-insight.eu/en/public-2/the-insight-mission/instruments-deployment|title=Instruments Deployment - SEIS / Mars InSight|website=www.seis-insight.eu|access-date=2018-12-26}}</ref> The total mass of the system is approximately {{cvt|3|kg|abbr=on}} and it consumes a maximum of {{Val|2|u=[[watt]]s}} while the mole is active.<ref name=\"Home HP3\">{{cite web |title=Heat Probe {{!}} Instruments |url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/instruments/hp3 |website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander |accessdate=13 April 2020 |language=en}}</ref>

column2: the mole uses a motor and a gearbox (provided by [[Maxon Motor AG|Maxon]]) and a cammed roller that periodically loads a spring connected to a rod that functions as a hammer. After release from the cam
column3: the hammer accelerates downwards to hit the outer casing and cause its penetration through the [[regolith]]. Meanwhile a suppressor mass travels upwards and its kinetic energy is compensated by gravitational potential and compression of a brake spring and wire helix on the opposite side of the mole.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/>

column2: every {{cvt|50|cm}} the probe puts out a pulse of heat and its sensors measure how the heat pulse changes with time. If the [[Crust (geology)|crust]] material is a thermal conductor
column4: the pulse will decay quickly.<ref name=\"Home HP3\" />  The mole is first allowed to cool down for two days
column5: then it is heated to about {{cvt|10|C|F|abbr=on}} over 24 hours. Temperature sensors within the tether measure how rapidly this happens
column6: which tells scientists the thermal conductivity of the soil.<ref>{{cite web |title=NASA's InSight Prepares to Take Mars' Temperature |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7335 |website=NASA/JPL |accessdate=13 April 2020 |date=February 13
column7: 2019}}</ref> Together
column8: these measurements yield the rate of heat flowing from the interior.

column1: The HP<sup>3</sup> mole was originally expected to take about 40 days to reach {{cvt|5|m|abbr=on}} deep.<ref>{{cite web |title=Surface Operations |url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/timeline/surface-operations/ |website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander |accessdate=13 April 2020 |language=en}}</ref> As the mole burrows
column2: it also generates vibrations that SEIS can detect
column3: which may yield information about the Martian subsurface.<ref name=\"mars.nasa.gov\" />

column1: | caption1          = Animation of HP<sup>3</sup> being deployed to the surface by InSight's robotic arm (IDA).
| caption2          = Animation of HP<sup>3</sup> mole burrowing into Mars.

column2: the HP<sup>3</sup> began burrowing into the surface sand
column3: but became stalled after several centimeters by what was initially suspected to be a large rock.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dickinson |first1=David |title=Mars Insight's \"Mole\" Hits a Snag |url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/mars-insight-drill-hits-snag/ |website=Sky & Telescope |publisher=AAS Sky Publishing
column4: LLC. |accessdate=1 September 2019 |date=11 March 2019}}</ref> Further analysis and testing with a replica model on Earth suggested the problem may be due to insufficient friction. In June 2019
column5: more evidence for this was revealed when the support structure was lifted off of the HP<sup>3</sup> mole. The Martian regolith appeared to be compressed
column6: leaving a gap around the probe.

column2: using the lander's robotic arm to press on the soil near the probe to increase soil friction.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/nasas-strategy-mars-insight-back-drilling/|title=A Strategy to Get the Mars Insight Lander Back in the Drilling Business|last=Dickinson|first=David|date=2019-07-03|website=Sky & Telescope |publisher=AAS Sky Publishing
column3: LLC. |language=en-US|access-date=2019-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7441|title=NASA's InSight Uncovers the 'Mole'|website=NASA/JPL|access-date=2019-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/here-s-how-nasa-might-rescue-insight-s-extremely-stuck-1838750453|title=Here's How NASA Might Rescue InSight's Extremely Stuck Heat Probe|last=Dvorsky|first=George|website=Gizmodo|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-04}}</ref><ref name=\":0\" /> Utimately
column4: this method was not able to generate enough downward force
column5: since the HP<sup>3</sup> probe was at the limit of the arm's range.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.universetoday.com/143782/success-nasa-confirms-the-mole-is-working-again/|title=Success! NASA Confirms the Mole is Working Again.|last=Gough|first=Evan|date=2019-10-18|website=Universe Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref>

column2: the team used the robotic scoop to pin the probe against the edge of its hole. This method appeared successful initially
column3: as the probe continued to dig for two weeks
column4: until it was flush with the surface.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/nasa-mars-lander-may-be-able-to-save-its-stuck-mole/|title=NASA Mars lander may be able to save its stuck 'mole'|last=Kooser|first=Amanda|website=CNET|language=en|access-date=2019-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/mars-insights-mole-is-moving-again|title=Mars InSight's 'Mole' Is Moving Again|last=Greicius|first=Tony|date=2019-10-17|website=NASA|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> At this time
column5: the exposed top of the probe was too small for the scoop to press against
column6: so the scoop was re-positioned to press down on the soil near the probe. Unfortunately
column7: this caused the probe to back out again due to unusual soil properties and low atmospheric pressure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/news/8529/mars-insights-mole-has-partially-backed-out-of-its-hole?site=insight|title=Mars InSight's Mole Has Partially Backed Out of Its Hole|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2019-10-28}}</ref> As the probe bounced
column8: loose soil filled the area beneath it and lifted the probe halfway out again.<ref name=\"NPR Nov29\">{{cite web |last1=Palca |first1=Joe |title=A 'Mole' Isn't Digging Mars: NASA Engineers Are Trying To Find Out Why |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/11/29/783278261/a-mole-isn-t-digging-mars-nasa-engineers-are-trying-to-find-out-why |website=NPR.org |accessdate=29 November 2019 |language=en |date=Nov 29
column9: 2019}}</ref> In January 2020
column10: the team used the pinning method again
column11: but once again the probe ejected after the scoop was repositioned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spacenews.com/insight-to-try-to-push-mole-into-martian-surface/|title=InSight to try to push mole into Martian surface|date=2020-02-21|website=SpaceNews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-25}}</ref>

column2: the team reevaluated the risks of pushing the scoop directly against the back cap of the mole
column3: and determined the procedure to be acceptable. The procedure appears to be successful
column4: {{asof|2020|3|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite tweet |user= NASAInSight |number=1238497770228420608 |date= March 13
column5: 2020 |title= A bit of good news from #Mars }}</ref>

column1: | title        = Efforts of HP<sup>3</sup> to penetrate the Martian surface
| Engineering analysis of the mole after the initial problem concluded that the bottom of the mole was about {{convert|12|-|14|in|cm}} deep into Martian ground
column2: with a bit of its top still inside the HP<sup>3</sup> support structure.

column1: | ''Insight''{{'s}} HP<sup>3</sup> components after lifting the support structure away from the mole. This image shows a region of compressed regolith around the Mole penetrometer.
| File:Mars InSight Mole Progress October 2019 8529 PIA23379-web 630.gif
| The initial success of the pinning technique is depicted in this animation
column2: which shows the probe burrowing into the regolith.

column1: | HP<sup>3</sup> is seen after backing about halfway out of the hole it had burrowed.
| Insight lander using its scoop to push on the back cap of the HP<sup>3</sup> mole.
The HP<sup>3</sup> includes an infrared [[radiometer]] for measuring surface temperatures
column2: contributed by DLR and based on the MARA radiometer for the ''[[Hayabusa2]]'' mission.{{r|Banerdt20130307|in-depth|Grott2017}} HP3-RAD uses [[thermopile]] detectors to measure three spectral bands: {{val|8|-|14|u=um}}
column3: {{val|16|-|19|u=um}} and {{val|7.8|-|9.6|u=um}}.<ref name=\":1\" />  HP3-RAD has a mass of {{cvt|120|g}}.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The detector was protected by a removable cover during landing.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite journal|last=Kopp|first=Emanuel|last2=Mueller|first2=Nils|last3=Grott|first3=Matthias|last4=Walter|first4=Ingo|last5=Knollenberg|first5=Jörg|last6=Hanschke|first6=Frank|last7=Kessler|first7=Ernst|last8=Meyer|first8=Hans-Georg|date=2016-09-01|title=HP3-RAD: a compact radiometer design with on-site calibration for in-situ exploration|journal=Infrared Remote Sensing and Instrumentation Xxiv|volume=9973|pages=99730T|doi=10.1117/12.2236190|bibcode=2016SPIE.9973E..0TK|url=https://elib.dlr.de/105959/1/SPIE-2016-Paper%209973-28-HP3-RAD-A%20compact%20radiometer%20design.pdf}}</ref> The cover also serves as a [[calibration target]] for the instrument
column2: supporting on-site calibration of the HP3-RAD.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: Infrared radiometers were sent to Mars in 1969 as one of four major instruments on the [[Mariner 6 and 7|Mariner 6 and Mariner 7]] flyby spacecraft
column2: and the observations helped to trigger a scientific revolution in knowledge about Mars.<ref name=\"acs.org\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/education/whatischemistry/landmarks/mars-infrared-spectrometer.html|title=Infrared Spectrometer and the Exploration of Mars|website=American Chemical Society|language=en|access-date=2018-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chdse|first=S. C.|date=1969-03-01|title=Infrared radiometer for the 1969 mariner mission to Mars|journal=Applied Optics|volume=8|issue=3|pages=639|doi=10.1364/AO.8.000639|issn=1559-128X|pmid=20072273}}</ref> The Mariner 6 & 7 infrared radiometer results showed that the [[atmosphere of Mars]] is composed mostly of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>)
column3: and revealed trace amounts [[Water on Mars|water on the surface of Mars]].<ref name=\"acs.org\"/>

column2: an infrared instrument on the 2003 [[Mars Exploration Rovers]]

column1: *[http://esmats.eu/amspapers/pastpapers/pdfs/2016/grygorczuk2.pdf Hammering Mechanism for the HP3 Experiment onboard ''InSight''.] (PDF)

column2:
{{Use dmy dates|date = January 2019}} {{Use American English|date = January 2019}} {{Short description|Scientific instrument of the InSight Mars lander}} {{Infobox spacecraft instrument | Name = Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package {{nowrap|(HP3)}} | Image = Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package (HP3) (cropped).png | Caption = Artist's impression of HP3 on the surface of Mars | Operator = [[NASA]] | Manufacturer = [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR) | Type = [[radiometer|infrared radiometer]],
thermal conductivity sensor | Function = [[Geology of Mars|Geophysics of Mars]] | Mission_Duration = 2 years on Mars (planned) | Began = Landing: 26 November 2018 | Ceased = | Webpage = {{url|https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/instruments/hp3/}} | Mass = {{convert|3|kg|abbr=on}} | Power_consumption = 2 [[watt]]s | Data_Rate = | Spacecraft = ''[[InSight]]'' Mars lander | SC_Operator = NASA | Launch = {{start-date|5 May 2018, 11:05}} [[UTC]] | Rocket = [[Atlas V]] 401{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1312/19insight/ |title=Mars lander to launch from California on Atlas 5 in 2016 |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=20 December 2013}}

column1: | Launch_Site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 3|SLC-3E]]<ref name=\"Atlas V\"/>

The '''Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package''' ('''HP<sup>3</sup>''') is a science payload onboard the ''[[InSight]]'' lander that features instruments to study the heat flow and other thermal properties of [[Mars]]. One of the instruments
column3: is designed to penetrate {{Cvt|5|m}} below Mars' surface. In March 2019
column4: the mole successfully burrowed a few centimeters
column5: but then became unable to continue. In the following year further efforts were made to resolve the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/307933-nasa-uses-insights-robotic-arm-to-push-heat-probe-into-mars|title=NASA Uses InSight's Robotic Arm to Push Heat Probe Into Mars - ExtremeTech|website=www.extremetech.com|access-date=2020-03-22}}</ref>

column1: HP<sup>3</sup> was provided by the [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR). The hammering mechanism inside the mole was designed by the Polish company [[Astronika]] and the Space Research Centre of the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]] under contract and in cooperation with DLR.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://scienceinpoland.pap.pl/en/news/news
column3: polish-kret-will-fly-to-mars.html |title=Polish Kret will fly to Mars |work=Science in Poland |access-date=2018-05-05 |language=en}}</ref>

column1: The Principal Investigator is Tilman Spohn from the German Aerospace Center.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3}}

The mission aims to understand the origin and diversity of [[terrestrial planet]]s.<ref name=\"octoberpres\">{{cite conference |url=https://mepag.jpl.nasa.gov/meeting/2012-10/10_2012-1004_MEPAG.pdf |title=InSight – Geophysical Mission to Mars |conference=26th Mars Exploration Program Analysis Group Meeting. 4 October 2012. Monrovia
column2: California. |first=W. Bruce |last=Banerdt |date=2012}}</ref> Information from the HP<sup>3</sup> heat flow package is expected to reveal whether Mars and Earth formed from the same material
column3: and determine how active the interior of Mars is today.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3|flow}}<ref name=\"nasapr20120820\">{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mars/news/insight20120820.html |title=New Insight on Mars Expected From new NASA Mission |publisher=NASA |first=D. C. |last=Agle |date=20 August 2012}}</ref> Additional science goals include determining the thickness of Mars' crust
column4: the composition of its mantle
column5: and thermal characteristics of the interior
column6: such as the temperature gradient and heat flux.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/science/goals|title=Goals {{!}} Science|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2019-09-03}}</ref>

column2: the mission will estimate the size of Mars' [[Planetary core|core]] and whether the core is liquid or solid.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.universetoday.com/93843/nasas-proposed-insight-lander-would-peer-to-the-center-of-mars-in-2016/ |title=NASAs Proposed 'InSight' Lander would Peer to the Center of Mars in 2016 |work=Universe Today |first=Ken |last=Kremer |date=2 March 2012 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> The vibrations generated by the mole will be monitored by SEIS to learn about the local subsurface.<ref name=\"mars.nasa.gov\">{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/timeline/surface-operations|title=Surface Operations {{!}} Timeline|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2018-12-24}}</ref>
HP<sup>3</sup> includes an infrared [[radiometer]] (HP3-RAD) mounted to the landing platform
column3: also contributed by DLR.<ref name=\"Banerdt20130307\">{{cite conference |url=http://sites.nationalacademies.org/cs/groups/ssbsite/documents/webpage/ssb_086912.pdf |title=InSight: A Geophysical Mission to a Terrestrial Planet Interior |conference=Committee on Astrobiology and Planetary Science. 6–8 March 2013. Washington
column4: D.C. |first=W. Bruce |last=Banerdt |date=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"in-depth\">{{Cite news |url=https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/insight/in-depth/ |title=InSight: In Depth |work=Solar System Exploration |publisher=NASA |access-date=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=\"Grott2017\">{{cite journal |title=The MASCOT Radiometer MARA for the Hayabusa 2 Mission |journal=Space Science Reviews |first1=M. |last1=Grott |first2=J. |last2=Knollenberg |first3=B. |last3=Borgs |first4=F. |last4=Hänschke |first5=E. |last5=Kessler |first6=J. |last6=Helbert |first7=A. |last7=Maturilli |first8=N. |last8=Müller |display-authors=1 |volume=208 |issue=1–4 |pages=413–431 |date=July 2017 |doi=10.1007/s11214-016-0272-1 |bibcode=2017SSRv..208..413G}}</ref>

column1: {{stack|[[File:InSight's HP3 instrument diagram.png|thumb|upright=1.2|Diagram showing the components of HP<sup>3</sup>]]}}

The HP<sup>3</sup> heat flow probe is made up of the following subsystems:<ref name=\"DLR\">{{cite web |title=HP3 heat flow probe |url=https://www.dlr.de/dlr/en/desktopdefault.aspx/tabid-11038/1865_read-27097/ |website=DLR Portal |accessdate=2 September 2019 |language=en}}</ref>
**'''Engineering tether''' (ET) to communicate between the support structure to the lander
**'''Science tether''' (TEM-P) a [[Flexible electronics|flex PCB]] with 14 platinum [[Resistance thermometer|RTDs]] for measuring thermal properties of the regolith.
**'''Tether length monitor''' (TLM) optical length meter for measuring the deployed length of the science tether
* '''Mole penetrometer''' for burrowing beneath the surface
** '''STATIL''' [[tiltmeter]] for determining orientation and direction of the mole.
[[File:InSight's HP3 instrument Image-36-full.jpg|thumb|HP<sup>3</sup> before launch. Left to right:  mole
column4: and engineering tether.]]

column1: HP<sup>3</sup> was conceived by Gromov V. V. et al. in 1997
column2: <ref name='Hammering mechanism'/><ref>Gromov V.V. et al.: ''The mobile penetrometer
column3: a \"mole\" for sub-surface soil investigation.'' In Proc. of 7th European Space Mechanisms and Tribology Symposium. 1997.</ref> and first flown as the PLUTO instrument on the failed 2003 ''[[Beagle 2]]'' Mars lander mission.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/> HP<sup>3</sup> evolved further and it was proposed in 2001 for a mission to [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]
column4: <ref name='proposals'>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/223287921_A_heat_flow_and_physical_properties_package_for_the_surface_of_Mercury A heat flow and physical properties package for the surface of Mercury].  Tilman Spohn
column5: Karsten Seiferlin. ''Planetary and Space Science'' 49(14-15):1571-1577 December 2001. {{doi|10.1016/S0032-0633(01)00094-0}}</ref> in 2009 to the [[European Space Agency]] as part of the Humboldt payload onboard the [[ExoMars]] lander
column6: <ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009EGUGA..1113520K HP3 on ExoMars]. Krause
column7: C.; Izzo
column8: M.; Re
column9: E.; Mehls
column10: C.; Richter
column11: L.; Coste
column12: P. EGU General Assembly 2009
column13: held 19–24 April 2009 in Vienna
column14: Austria.</ref><ref name='proposals'/> in 2010 for a mission to the Moon
column15: <ref>[https://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lunargeo2010/pdf/3016.pdf Measuring heat flow on the Moon — The Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package HP3.] (PDF) T. Spohn
column19: and the HP3 instrument team. Ground-based Geophysics on the Moon (2010). Lunar and Planetary Institute
column20: conference 2010.</ref> and in 2011 it was proposed to NASA's [[Discovery Program]] as a payload for ''InSight'' Mars lander
column21: known at that time as GEMS (Geophysical Monitoring Station).<ref name=\"flow\">{{cite conference |url=http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EPSC-DPS2011/EPSC-DPS2011-379-1.pdf |title=Measuring Heat Flow on Mars: The Heat Flow and Physical Properties Package on GEMS |conference=EPSC-DPS Joint Meeting 2011. 2–7 October 2011. Nantes
column22: France. |first1=M. |last1=Grott |first2=T. |last2=Spohn |first3=W. B. |last3=Banerdt |first4=S. |last4=Smrekar |first5=T. L. |last5=Hudson |display-authors=etal |date=October 2011 |bibcode=2011epsc.conf..379G |id=EPSC-DPS2011-379-1}}</ref> ''InSight'' was launched on 5 May 2018 and landed on 26 November 2018.

column1: The mole is described as a \"self-hammering nail\" and was designed to burrow below the Martian surface while trailing a tether with embedded heaters and temperature sensors. The goal is to measure the thermal properties of Mars' interior
column2: and thus reveal unique information about the planet's geologic history.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'>[http://esmats.eu/amspapers/pastpapers/pdfs/2016/grygorczuk2.pdf Hammering Mechanism for HP3 Experiment (InSight)]. (PDF) Jerzy Grygorczuk1
column4: Bartosz Kędziora1
column5: Maciej Borys
column6: Rafał Przybyła1
column7: Tomasz Kuciński1
column8: Maciej Ossowski
column9: Wojciech Konior
column10: Olaf Krömer
column11: Tilman Spohn
column12: Marta Tokarz and Mateusz Białek. ''European Space Mechanisms and Tribology Symposium''; 2016.</ref>

column1: The burrowing mole is a pointed cylinder with a smooth outer surface approximately {{cvt|35|cm}} in length and {{cvt|3.5|cm}} in diameter. It contains a heater to determine thermal conductivity during descent
column2: and it trails a tether equipped with precise heat sensors placed at {{convert|10|cm|abbr=on}} intervals to measure the temperature profile of the subsurface.{{r|octoberpres|Home HP3}}

column1: The mole penetrator unit is designed to be placed near the lander in an area about 3-m long and 2-m wide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.seis-insight.eu/en/public-2/the-insight-mission/instruments-deployment|title=Instruments Deployment - SEIS / Mars InSight|website=www.seis-insight.eu|access-date=2018-12-26}}</ref> The total mass of the system is approximately {{cvt|3|kg|abbr=on}} and it consumes a maximum of {{Val|2|u=[[watt]]s}} while the mole is active.<ref name=\"Home HP3\">{{cite web |title=Heat Probe {{!}} Instruments |url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/mission/instruments/hp3 |website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander |accessdate=13 April 2020 |language=en}}</ref>

column2: the mole uses a motor and a gearbox (provided by [[Maxon Motor AG|Maxon]]) and a cammed roller that periodically loads a spring connected to a rod that functions as a hammer. After release from the cam
column3: the hammer accelerates downwards to hit the outer casing and cause its penetration through the [[regolith]]. Meanwhile a suppressor mass travels upwards and its kinetic energy is compensated by gravitational potential and compression of a brake spring and wire helix on the opposite side of the mole.<ref name='Hammering mechanism'/>

column2: every {{cvt|50|cm}} the probe puts out a pulse of heat and its sensors measure how the heat pulse changes with time. If the [[Crust (geology)|crust]] material is a thermal conductor
column4: the pulse will decay quickly.<ref name=\"Home HP3\" />  The mole is first allowed to cool down for two days
column5: then it is heated to about {{cvt|10|C|F|abbr=on}} over 24 hours. Temperature sensors within the tether measure how rapidly this happens
column6: which tells scientists the thermal conductivity of the soil.<ref>{{cite web |title=NASA's InSight Prepares to Take Mars' Temperature |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7335 |website=NASA/JPL |accessdate=13 April 2020 |date=February 13
column7: 2019}}</ref> Together
column8: these measurements yield the rate of heat flowing from the interior.

column1: The HP<sup>3</sup> mole was originally expected to take about 40 days to reach {{cvt|5|m|abbr=on}} deep.<ref>{{cite web |title=Surface Operations |url=https://mars.nasa.gov/insight/timeline/surface-operations/ |website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander |accessdate=13 April 2020 |language=en}}</ref> As the mole burrows
column2: it also generates vibrations that SEIS can detect
column3: which may yield information about the Martian subsurface.<ref name=\"mars.nasa.gov\" />

column1: | caption1          = Animation of HP<sup>3</sup> being deployed to the surface by InSight's robotic arm (IDA).
| caption2          = Animation of HP<sup>3</sup> mole burrowing into Mars.

column2: the HP<sup>3</sup> began burrowing into the surface sand
column3: but became stalled after several centimeters by what was initially suspected to be a large rock.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dickinson |first1=David |title=Mars Insight's \"Mole\" Hits a Snag |url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/mars-insight-drill-hits-snag/ |website=Sky & Telescope |publisher=AAS Sky Publishing
column4: LLC. |accessdate=1 September 2019 |date=11 March 2019}}</ref> Further analysis and testing with a replica model on Earth suggested the problem may be due to insufficient friction. In June 2019
column5: more evidence for this was revealed when the support structure was lifted off of the HP<sup>3</sup> mole. The Martian regolith appeared to be compressed
column6: leaving a gap around the probe.

column2: using the lander's robotic arm to press on the soil near the probe to increase soil friction.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/nasas-strategy-mars-insight-back-drilling/|title=A Strategy to Get the Mars Insight Lander Back in the Drilling Business|last=Dickinson|first=David|date=2019-07-03|website=Sky & Telescope |publisher=AAS Sky Publishing
column3: LLC. |language=en-US|access-date=2019-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7441|title=NASA's InSight Uncovers the 'Mole'|website=NASA/JPL|access-date=2019-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/here-s-how-nasa-might-rescue-insight-s-extremely-stuck-1838750453|title=Here's How NASA Might Rescue InSight's Extremely Stuck Heat Probe|last=Dvorsky|first=George|website=Gizmodo|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-04}}</ref><ref name=\":0\" /> Utimately
column4: this method was not able to generate enough downward force
column5: since the HP<sup>3</sup> probe was at the limit of the arm's range.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.universetoday.com/143782/success-nasa-confirms-the-mole-is-working-again/|title=Success! NASA Confirms the Mole is Working Again.|last=Gough|first=Evan|date=2019-10-18|website=Universe Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref>

column2: the team used the robotic scoop to pin the probe against the edge of its hole. This method appeared successful initially
column3: as the probe continued to dig for two weeks
column4: until it was flush with the surface.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/nasa-mars-lander-may-be-able-to-save-its-stuck-mole/|title=NASA Mars lander may be able to save its stuck 'mole'|last=Kooser|first=Amanda|website=CNET|language=en|access-date=2019-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/mars-insights-mole-is-moving-again|title=Mars InSight's 'Mole' Is Moving Again|last=Greicius|first=Tony|date=2019-10-17|website=NASA|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> At this time
column5: the exposed top of the probe was too small for the scoop to press against
column6: so the scoop was re-positioned to press down on the soil near the probe. Unfortunately
column7: this caused the probe to back out again due to unusual soil properties and low atmospheric pressure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mars.nasa.gov/news/8529/mars-insights-mole-has-partially-backed-out-of-its-hole?site=insight|title=Mars InSight's Mole Has Partially Backed Out of Its Hole|last=mars.nasa.gov|website=NASA's InSight Mars Lander|language=en|access-date=2019-10-28}}</ref> As the probe bounced
column8: loose soil filled the area beneath it and lifted the probe halfway out again.<ref name=\"NPR Nov29\">{{cite web |last1=Palca |first1=Joe |title=A 'Mole' Isn't Digging Mars: NASA Engineers Are Trying To Find Out Why |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/11/29/783278261/a-mole-isn-t-digging-mars-nasa-engineers-are-trying-to-find-out-why |website=NPR.org |accessdate=29 November 2019 |language=en |date=Nov 29
column9: 2019}}</ref> In January 2020
column10: the team used the pinning method again
column11: but once again the probe ejected after the scoop was repositioned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spacenews.com/insight-to-try-to-push-mole-into-martian-surface/|title=InSight to try to push mole into Martian surface|date=2020-02-21|website=SpaceNews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-25}}</ref>

column2: the team reevaluated the risks of pushing the scoop directly against the back cap of the mole
column3: and determined the procedure to be acceptable. The procedure appears to be successful
column4: {{asof|2020|3|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite tweet |user= NASAInSight |number=1238497770228420608 |date= March 13
column5: 2020 |title= A bit of good news from #Mars }}</ref>

column1: | title        = Efforts of HP<sup>3</sup> to penetrate the Martian surface
| Engineering analysis of the mole after the initial problem concluded that the bottom of the mole was about {{convert|12|-|14|in|cm}} deep into Martian ground
column2: with a bit of its top still inside the HP<sup>3</sup> support structure.

column1: | ''Insight''{{'s}} HP<sup>3</sup> components after lifting the support structure away from the mole. This image shows a region of compressed regolith around the Mole penetrometer.
| File:Mars InSight Mole Progress October 2019 8529 PIA23379-web 630.gif
| The initial success of the pinning technique is depicted in this animation
column2: which shows the probe burrowing into the regolith.

column1: | HP<sup>3</sup> is seen after backing about halfway out of the hole it had burrowed.
| Insight lander using its scoop to push on the back cap of the HP<sup>3</sup> mole.
The HP<sup>3</sup> includes an infrared [[radiometer]] for measuring surface temperatures
column2: contributed by DLR and based on the MARA radiometer for the ''[[Hayabusa2]]'' mission.{{r|Banerdt20130307|in-depth|Grott2017}} HP3-RAD uses [[thermopile]] detectors to measure three spectral bands: {{val|8|-|14|u=um}}
column3: {{val|16|-|19|u=um}} and {{val|7.8|-|9.6|u=um}}.<ref name=\":1\" />  HP3-RAD has a mass of {{cvt|120|g}} (about a quarter pound).<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The detector was protected by a removable cover during landing.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite journal|last=Kopp|first=Emanuel|last2=Mueller|first2=Nils|last3=Grott|first3=Matthias|last4=Walter|first4=Ingo|last5=Knollenberg|first5=Jörg|last6=Hanschke|first6=Frank|last7=Kessler|first7=Ernst|last8=Meyer|first8=Hans-Georg|date=2016-09-01|title=HP3-RAD: a compact radiometer design with on-site calibration for in-situ exploration|journal=Infrared Remote Sensing and Instrumentation Xxiv|volume=9973|pages=99730T|doi=10.1117/12.2236190|bibcode=2016SPIE.9973E..0TK|url=https://elib.dlr.de/105959/1/SPIE-2016-Paper%209973-28-HP3-RAD-A%20compact%20radiometer%20design.pdf}}</ref> The cover also serves as a [[calibration target]] for the instrument
column2: supporting on-site calibration of the HP3-RAD.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: Infrared radiometers were sent to Mars in 1969 as one of four major instruments on the [[Mariner 6 and 7|Mariner 6 and Mariner 7]] flyby spacecraft
column2: and the observations helped to trigger a scientific revolution in knowledge about Mars.<ref name=\"acs.org\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/education/whatischemistry/landmarks/mars-infrared-spectrometer.html|title=Infrared Spectrometer and the Exploration of Mars|website=American Chemical Society|language=en|access-date=2018-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chdse|first=S. C.|date=1969-03-01|title=Infrared radiometer for the 1969 mariner mission to Mars|journal=Applied Optics|volume=8|issue=3|pages=639|doi=10.1364/AO.8.000639|issn=1559-128X|pmid=20072273}}</ref> The Mariner 6 & 7 infrared radiometer results showed that the [[atmosphere of Mars]] is composed mostly of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>)
column3: and revealed trace amounts [[Water on Mars|water on the surface of Mars]].<ref name=\"acs.org\"/>

column2: an infrared instrument on the 2003 [[Mars Exploration Rovers]]

column2: there had been 18 confirmed cases in total.<ref name=\"barbadostoday1\">{{Cite web|url=https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/03/24/covid-19-update-only-one-new-case-today/ |title=COVID- 19 Update: Only one new case today |date=24 March 2020 |work=Barbados Today}}</ref>
the Minister of Health announced that the total number of cases reached 26. By that date
column3: Barbados had conducted 234 tests overall.<ref name=\"loop-27march\">{{cite news |title=Barbados COVID-19 cases stand at 26 as of March 27
column4: 1 pm |url=http://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/barbados-covid-19-cases-jump-26-march-27-1-pm |access-date=28 March 2020 |date=27 March 2020 |work=Loop News}}</ref>
announced seven new cases taking the total number of cases up to 33. Of those cases 19 were imported
column5: 11 were identified through contact tracing
column6: and 2 were still being investigated. 16 of the cases were males and 17 were females. By that date
column7: Barbados had conducted 287 tests overall and there was no evidence of [[community transmission|community spread]].<ref name=\"gisbarbados-29march\">{{cite news |title=COVID-19 Update: National Count At 33 |url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/covid-19-update-national-count-at-33/ |date=29 March 2020 |work=GIS Barbados}}</ref>

column2: Minister of Health and Wellness Jeffrey Bostic announced one new case
column3: bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 34.<ref name=\"Nationnews-30march\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244713/34-confirmed-covid-19-barbados|title=34 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Barbados |date= 30 March 2020 | work= nationnews}}</ref>

column2: acting Prime Minister Santia Bradshaw announced that 11 tests were positive the day before
column4: bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 45 and the total number of tests performed to 382.<ref name=\"youtube-31march\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AEgVlrCjCqA |title=COVID-19 Update (1st April
column5: 2020) feat. Acting PM Hon. Santia Bradshaw
column6: M.P |date=1 April 2020 | work=PMOBarbados YouTube Channel}}</ref>

column2: there had been 52 confirmed cases in total
column3: with ages ranging form 17 to 83 years old. 27 were male and 25 were female.<ref name=\"nationnews-4april\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244816/covid |title=COVID cases now at 52 |date=4 April 2020| work=Nation News}}</ref> By that date all cases were still active - there had been no deaths or recoveries.<ref name=\"gisinstagram-4april\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/B-kM0jIA-04/ |title=The Ministry of Health and Wellness' #COVID19 Situation Dashboard for Saturday
column4: April 4
column5: 2020 |date=4 April 2020| work=GIS Barbados' Instagram Account}}</ref>

column2: the Minister of Health and Wellness made several announcements in a live stream:<ref name=\"pmobarbadosyoutube-5april\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ybHYYXZypQ |title=Press Conference & COVID-19 Update (April 5
an 81-year-old male with underlying conditions who had returned to Barbados from the UK on 22 March.

column1: * The country also recorded its first six recoveries: four males and two females who would be discharged from isolation in medical facilities that day.
* Four new cases were also announced
column2: bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 56 (28 male and 28 female) out of 527 tests
column3: the majority of cases being mild to moderate.

column1: * Only three ventilators had been used up to that date out of 37 owned by the government and 11 owned by the private sector and made available to the government. 150 ventilators were on order from various sources. An order of 20 ventilators paid for by a philanthropist had been seized by the US government. 5 ventilators donated by [[Rihanna]] were expected to reach Barbados by the following week.

* The medical facility at Harrison Point with 220 beds would be handed over from contractors to the Ministry of Health and Wellness the following day so the ministry could begin installing medical equipment.
* A team of 100 intensive care specialists would be arriving from Cuba that day and would be tested on arrival. They would start working at the Harrison Point facility upon its completion.
* There was still no evidence of community spread.
Since shortly after the first confirmed case
column2: daily updates have been given to the public by various members of [[Government of Barbados|government]] and medical community including: [[Prime Minister of Barbados|Prime Minister]]
column3: [[Mia Mottley]]; Acting Prime Minister and Minister of Education
column4: Santia Bradshaw; [[Ministry_of_Health_%26_Wellness|Minister of Health and Wellness]]
column5: Lt Col Jeffrey Bostic; Acting Chief Medical Officer
column6: Dr. Anton Best; Head of Infectious Diseases at the [[Queen Elizabeth Hospital
column7: Bridgetown|Queen Elizabeth Hospital]]
column8: Dr Corey Forde; COVID-19 [[Czar_(political_term)|Czar]]
column9: Richard Carter.

column1: The government has set up three locations to be used for quarantine and/or isolation:<ref name=\"gis-5april\">{{Cite web |url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/majority-of-covid-19-patients-are-stable/ |title=Majority Of COVID-19 Patients Are Stable |date=5 April 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Barbados GIS}}</ref>
Construction on an additional isolation facility at Harrison Point
column2: St Lucy has been completed and was handed over to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital on 8 April to be outfitted with furniture and equipment. The facility has a capacity for over 200 beds.<ref name=\"loop-8april\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/harrison-point-facility-handed-over-qeh-covid-19-patients |title=Harrison Point facility handed over to QEH for COVID-19 patients |date=8 April 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Barbados GIS}}</ref> The team of 100 intensive care specialists from [[Cuba]] will be stationed at Harrison Point once it's completed.<ref name=\"pmobarbadosyoutube-5april\" />
the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory because one of the first labs in the Caribbean to be ready for [[COVID-19 testing]]
column4: test kits and reagents in collaboration with the [[Pan American Health Organization]] (PAHO) and the [[Ministry of Health & Wellness]].<ref name=\"paho-13feb\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.paho.org/spc-crb/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=605:paho-prepares-barbados-for-covid-19-testing&Itemid=0 |title=PAHO prepares Barbados for COVID-19 Testing |date=13 February 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=PAHO}}</ref> As of 12 April
column5: over 800 tests have been performed.<ref name=\"barbadostoday-12april\" />

column1: A COVID-19 hotline was setup (536-4500) and four stages were defined:<ref name=\"loop-17march\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/covid-19-management-and-response-plans-stage |title=COVID-19: Management and Response Plans by Stage |date=17 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Loop Barbados}}</ref>
* Stage 0: no cases. During this stage preparations would be made in anticipation of the virus' arrival.

* Stage 1: a confirmed case. Stage 1 was entered on 17 March when the first two confirmed cases were announced.<ref name=\"nation-17march\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244441/ministry-health-activates-stage-covid-19-response |title=Ministry of Health activates Stage 1 of COVID-19 response |date=17 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Nation News}}</ref>

* Stage 2: limited human-to-human spread. Stage 2 was entered on 21 March when the 14th confirmed case was announced.<ref name=\"nation-21march\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244533/covid-19-rise-14 |title=COVID-19 cases rise to 14 |date=21 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Nation News}}</ref>
* Stage 3: extensive human-to-human spread. Stage 3 was entered on 26 March when the 24th confirmed case was announced.<ref name=\"loop2\" />
The government has encouraged social distancing
column2: suggesting that people practise physical distancing of six feet<ref name=\"gisbarbados1\" />
column3: limiting the size of gatherings (initially to 100<ref name=\"nation-17march\" />
column4: then 25<ref name=\"btoday-22march\">{{Cite web |url=https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/03/22/limit-number-of-customers-in-stores/ |title=Limit number of customers in stores |date=22 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Barbados Today}}</ref>
column5: and eventually to three<ref name=\"gis-2april\" />) and strongly recommending wearing [[Cloth_facemask|cloth masks]] in public<ref name=\"gis-shopping-schedule-11april\" />. Restrictions have been placed on visitations at medical facilities and senior citizens homes
column6: while visitations at quarantine centres
column7: isolation centres and prisons have been prohibited.<ref name=\"gisbarbados1\" />

column1: All schools have been closed and some may look into the possibility of [[Educational technology|e-learning]] and [[Distance education|distance learning]]. National and regional exams such as common entrance and [[Caribbean Examinations Council|CXC]] have been postponed.<ref name=\"nation-11april\" />
All non-essential businesses including restaurants have been closed
column2: and shopping schedules have been implemented for supermarkets
column4: hardware stores and banks based on surname or special exceptions (senior citizens
column5: disabled people
column6: essential workers)
column7: with these businesses also being encouraged to explore options for e-commerce
column8: delivery and curbside pickups.<ref name=\"gis-2april\" /><ref name=\"gis-shopping-schedule-11april\" /><ref name=\"nation-7april\" /> Companies which support essential services are able to apply for an exception from the [[Attorney-General of Barbados|Attorney General]] to be able to operate.<ref name=\"nation-31march\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244744/businesses-seeking-exemption |title=More businesses seeking exemption |date=31 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Nation News}}</ref> NIS would create a system with additional workers for managing the increased number of people filing for [[unemployment benefits]].<ref name=\"nation-11april\" />

column1: The country's borders have not closed to commercial airline traffic though there are very few passenger flights still operating and some arriving passengers will be subject to a 14-day quarantine.<ref name=\"advocate-8april\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.barbadosadvocate.com/news/no-regrets |title=NO REGRETS! |date=8 April 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Barbados Advocate}}</ref><ref name=\"nation-22march\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244546/covid-19-tourism-update-flights-suspended |title=COVID-19 Tourism Update: Flights suspended |date=22 March 2020 |access-date=13 April 2020 |work=Barbados Advocate}}</ref>

column2: Prime Minister Mia Mottley announced that the country reached 24 cases and would be entering stage three of the COVID-19 National Preparedness Plan:<ref name=\"loop2\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/barbadians-enters-stage-3-curfew-march-28 |title=COVID-19: Barbados enters Stage 3
column3: curfew from March 28 |date=26 March 2020 |work=Loop Barbados}}</ref><ref name=\"gisbarbados1\">{{Cite web|url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020-fbclidiwar32cxrvq5zqfy0msm6nybss1_90a-nygoo3isvesndcghk-wagaik1dz48/ |title=Extracts - Emergency Management (COVID-19) Order
column4: 2020 |date=27 March 2020 |work=GIS Barbados}}</ref>

column1: * A public health emergency has been declared

column4: April 14
column5: 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.

column1: * Persons are confined to their places of residence during curfew hours
* Continue to practise physical distancing of six feet between persons
* The plan is being implemented in a phased manner based on the intensity of spread
Businesses in the private sector will be closed from 28 March 2020 by 8:00 pm until 15 April 2020
column2: except for those excluded by the government such as groceries
column4: gas stations and farms
column5: with specific allowed operating hours for each type of business. Restaurants can open but only for drive-through and take away services.

column1: People contravening the order without a reasonable explanation will be liable to a fine of BBD $50
column4: or both.

column2: acting Prime Minister Santia Bradshaw announced that because people were still congregating in large groups despite previous measures
column3: Barbados would be placed under a 24-hour curfew from 3 April 2020 at 6:00 pm. From that date
column4: all supermarkets
column5: mini marts
column6: restaurants
column7: government offices
column8: departments and statutory corporations would be closed
column9: the sale of alcohol would be prohibited
column10: and people would only be allowed to leave their homes to \"go to the pharmacy
column11: to seek medical assistance
column12: or if you are part of the essential services
column13: or if you are doing business with any of the businesses
column14: which are exempted under this Order\". Some food sellers
column16: bread depots and \"village shops\" would be allowed to operate during designated hours
column17: but could have no more than three people congregating at a time.<ref name=\"gis-2april\">{{Cite web|url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/24-hour-curfew-for-barbados-from-friday/ |title=24-Hour Curfew For Barbados From 6:00 p.m. Friday |date=2 April 2020 |accessdate=3 April 2020 | work=GIS Barbados}}</ref> The following day the start of the curfew was delayed till 8:00 pm. to allow workers time to go home after shutting up.<ref>{{cite news |title=51 cases of COVID-19

column4: supermarkets would reopen from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm to take orders online or over the phone for curbside pickup or delivery
column5: though customers would not be allowed to enter the supermarket. Some supermarkets would offer pre-packaged bundles with items of their choosing at [[Barbadian_dollar|BBD]] $25
column7: $100 or $150. Village shops and mini-marts would also be able to take orders and offer pre-packaged bundles.<ref name=\"nation-7april\">{{cite news |title=Guidelines for collecting groceries |url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244872/guidelines-collecting-groceries |date=7 April 2020 |work=Nation News}}</ref>

column2: Prime Minister Mia Mottley announced that the 24-hour curfew would be extended to end at midnight on the night of 3 May
column3: instead of 14 April.<ref name=\"nation-11april\">{{cite web |url=https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244948/curfew-extended |title=Curfew extended |date=11 April 2020 |work=Nation News}}</ref>

column1: The extension to the curfew meant that schools would no longer be able to reopen on 14 April
column2: so the ministry of education would be meeting with principals to discuss e-learning and distance learning
column3: as well a possible deferred date for the common entrance exams. Regional discussions would also be held to discuss plans for CXC exams.<ref name=\"nation-11april\" />

column1: The prime minister reminded the population that there was no shortage of food supplies in the country
column2: and that from 15 April hardwares and vendors of fruits and vegetables would once again be able to open. While curbside pickups and deliveries would continue
column4: fish markets
column5: hardwares and banks would also be implementing a new approach where customers would be allowed to do business on property on specific days and times of the week based on the first letter of their surname. The schedule would also allot special times for healthcare and other essential workers
column6: senior citizens and the disabled.<ref name=\"gis-shopping-schedule-11april\">{{cite web |url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/shopping-schedule-during-covid-19-curfew/ |title=Shopping Schedule During COVID -19 Curfew |date=11 April 2020 |work=GIS Barbados}}</ref><ref name=\"nation-11april\" />

column2: 000 unemployment benefit applications being filed<ref name=\"pmoyoutube-11april\">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1cyV-2sqj0w |title=Prime Minister Mia Amor Mottley's address to the Nation on matters of national importance. |date=11 April 2020 |work=PMOBarbados YouTube Channel}}</ref>
column3: NIS would create a separate system with additional workers for managing unemployment benefits. The first cheques would be available within 10 days
column4: and would cover 4 weeks instead of 1.<ref name=\"nation-11april\" />

column2: 000 test kits coming to the country through [[Pan American Health Organization|PAHO]] Barbados also purchased 20
column3: 000 kits at cost from the [[Cayman Islands]].<ref name=\"pmoyoutube-11april\" /> As of 11 April the country had performed 747 tests.<ref name=\"gis-11april\">{{Cite web|url=https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/covid-19-update-one-new-case-today/ |title=COVID-19 Update: One New Case Today |date=11 April 2020| work=Barbados GIS}}</ref>

column1: [[Category:2019–20 coronavirus pandemic by country and territory|Barbados]]

column2:
{{short description|Details of ongoing viral pandemic in Barbados}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox pandemic | name = 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Barbados | map1 = | legend1 = | map2 = | legend2 = | map3 = | legend3 = | disease = [[COVID-19]] | virus_strain = [[SARS-CoV-2]] | location = [[Barbados]] | first_case = | arrival_date = 17 March 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=3|day1=17|year1=2020|month2=|day2=|year2=}}) | origin = [[Wuhan]], [[China]] | confirmed_cases = 71{{Cite web|url=https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/12/covid-19-update-three-new-cases-today/ |title=COVID-19 Update: Three new cases today |date=12 April 2020| work=Barbados Today}}

column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was confirmed to have reached [[Barbados]] in March 2020.

column2: the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) confirmed that a [[novel coronavirus]] was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City
column4: China
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.<ref name=Elsevier>{{cite web |url=https://www.elsevier.com/connect/coronavirus-information-center |title=Novel Coronavirus Information Center |last=Elsevier |date= |website=Elsevier Connect|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200130171622/https://www.elsevier.com/connect/coronavirus-information-center|archive-date=30 January 2020|access-date=15 March 2020}}</ref><ref name=Reynolds4March2020>{{Cite news |last=Reynolds |first=Matt |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/china-coronavirus |title=What is coronavirus and how close is it to becoming a pandemic? |date=4 March 2020 |work=Wired UK|access-date=5 March 2020 |issn=1357-0978|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200305104806/https://www.wired.co.uk/article/china-coronavirus|archive-date=5 March 2020|url-status=live}}</ref>

column1: The [[Case fatality rate|case fatality ratio]] for COVID-19 has been much lower than [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome|SARS of 2003]]
column2: <ref name=Imperial13March2020>{{cite web |url= https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196137/crunching-numbers-coronavirus/ |title=Crunching the numbers for coronavirus |website=Imperial News|access-date=15 March 2020|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200319084913/https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196137/crunching-numbers-coronavirus/|archive-date=19 March 2020|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=Gov.ukHCIDDef>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/guidance/high-consequence-infectious-diseases-hcid |title=High consequence infectious diseases (HCID); Guidance and information about high consequence infectious diseases and their management in England |last= |first= |date= |website=GOV.UK |language=en|url-status=live|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200303051938/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/high-consequence-infectious-diseases-hcid|archive-date=3 March 2020|access-date=17 March 2020}}</ref> but the [[Transmission (medicine)|transmission]] has been significantly greater
column3: with a significant total death toll.<ref name=WFSA>{{cite web |url= https://www.wfsahq.org/resources/coronavirus |title=World Federation Of Societies of Anaesthesiologists – Coronavirus |last= |first= |date= |website=www.wfsahq.org|url-status=live|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200312233527/https://www.wfsahq.org/resources/coronavirus|archive-date=12 March 2020|access-date=15 March 2020}}</ref><ref name=Imperial13March2020/>
